abstract: Research Methodology for Information Sciences Quantitative Research --  Dr Cristian Rodriguez Rivero \x0c Objective of this lecture Introduce a multiple regression model as a means of relating a dependent variable â€œyâ€™â€™ to two or more independent variables â€˜High dimensional Dataâ€™, introduce Factor analysis involving Dimension reduction - why and how? Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c Outline \uf0d8Review on Correlation and Regression \uf0d8Multiple Regression Analysis \uf0d8Multi-dimensional problems spaces - why is this problematic \uf0d8Factor Analysis \uf0d8Ways of interpretation of findings Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c Review in Regression analysis The scatter plot must show a more or less linear relationship Otherwise constructing a linear regression line doesnâ€™t make sense Test the quality of the model! Regression Sum of Squares( SSR) Total Sum of Squares (SST) Error Sum of Squares (SSE) Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c Why dissect the total variation into two components? The goodness of fit of a regression is determined by the size of SSE If the fit is perfect, SSE = , then SSEâ‰  Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c Test of Significance of Regression Coefficient t- test for significance in simple linear regression If tcal >t tab at Î± % level of significance with (n-) df, then we reject H then we accept H F-test for significance, a summarize of ANOVA test for the regression coefficients, And p-values! Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c Multiple Regression Analysis Predicting the value of a variable based upon one or more independent variables Correlation coefficient is a measure for the effect size The intent is to look at the independent effect of each variable while â€œadjusting outâ€ the influence of potential confounders Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c Some assumption! Very high correlations between independent variable should be avoided \uf0d8This is Multicollinearity Create a correlation matrix and inspect for high correlations of  and above as this implies the two variables are measuring the same variance and will over-inflate R Therefore only one of the two variables is needed \uf0d8The Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) measures the degree to which collinearity among the predictors degrades the precision of an estimate Typically a VIF value greater than  is of concern Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c TYPES OF MULTIPLE REGRESSION â€¢Simultaneous: all independent variables entered together â€¢Stepwise: independent variables entered according to some order â€“By size or correlation with dependent variable â€“In order of significance â€¢Hierarchical: independent variables entered in stages Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c The Multiple Coefficient of Determination, R Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c Testing Global Usefulness of the Model Testing R \uf0d8Test R through an F test \uf0d8Test of competing models (difference between R) through an F test of difference of Rs Testing b \uf0d8Test of each partial regression coefficient (b) by t-tests \uf0d8Comparison of partial regression coefficients with each other - t-test of difference between standardized partial regression coefficients (\uf062) Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c Why to use parsimonious model ? A parsimonious model is a general linear model with a small number of \uf062 parameters In situations where two competing models have essentially the same predictive power (as determined by an F-test), choose the more parsimonious of the two Because What can happen is Quantitative Research Methods  CMRodriguez Rivero \x0c If the goal of the research is to use the model to predict or forecast the future mean value of the dependent variable, collinearity may not be a problem! If the goal is not prediction, but reliable estimation of the parameters, then collinearity is a serious problem Possible solutions: Dropping variables, acquire more data or a new sample, rethinking the model or transform the form of the variables Andâ€¦ Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c When Multicollinearity? Occurs when two or more Xâ€™s are correlated Some Indicators of multicollinearity: \uf0d8Highly correlated independent variables \uf0d8Significant, global F-test, but all t-tests nonsignificant \uf0d8Signs on coefficientâ€™s opposite from expected Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c High dimensional Data! Curse of dimensionality! (https://deepaiorg) Useful to learn lower dimensional representations of the data! Quantitative Research Methods  Resultado de imagen de high dimensional data \x0c Factor Analysis \uf0d8To identify underlying constructs (latent variables) in the data \uf0d8Removes redundancy or duplication from a set of correlated variables \uf0d8Represents correlated variables with a smaller set of â€œderivedâ€ variables \uf0d8Factors are formed that are relatively independent of one another \uf0d8Two types of â€œvariablesâ€: â€“ latent variables: factors (possible confounders!) â€“ observed variables Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Factor Analysis ) Identification of Underlying Factors: \uf0d8clusters variables into homogeneous sets \uf0d8creates new variables (ie factors) \uf0d8allows us to gain insight to categories ) Screening of Variables: \uf0d8identifies groupings to allow us to select one variable to represent many \uf0d8useful in regression (recall collinearity) Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Steps in Exploratory Factor Analysis () Collect data: choose relevant variables () Extract initial factors (via principal components) () Choose number of factors to retain () Choose estimation method, estimate model () Rotate and interpret () (a) Decide if changes need to be made (eg drop item(s), include item(s)) (b) repeat ()-() () Construct scales and use in further analysis Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Motivational Example: Frailty (the increasing frailty of old age) \uf0d8We have a concept of what â€œfrailtyâ€ is, but we canâ€™t measure it directly \uf0d8We think it combines strength, weight, speed, agility, balance, and perhaps other â€œfactorsâ€ \uf0d8We would like to be able to describe the components of frailty with a summary of strength, weight, etc Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Frailty Variables Speed of fast walk (+) Upper extremity strength (+) Speed of usual walk (+) Pinch strength (+) Time to do chair stands (-) Grip strength(+) Arm circumference (+) Knee extension (+) Body mass index (+) Hip extension (+) Tricep skin fold thickness (+) Time to do Pegboard test (-) Shoulder rotation (+) Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Factor Analysis Frailty Example (N=) Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Factor Analysis \uf0d8Factor analysis is totally dependent on correlations between variables \uf0d8Factor analysis summarizes correlation structure Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Factor Analysis One Factor Fragility Solution One Factor model Var(ej) = Ïƒj ,E(ej) =  Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Some key concepts! \uf0d8F is latent (ieunobserved, underlying) variable \uf0d8Xâ€™s are observed (ie manifest) variables \uf0d8ejis measurement error for Xj \uf0d8Î»jis the â€œloadingâ€for Xj To simplify our discussions, F is â€œstandardizedâ€(think â€œstandard normalâ€) Var(F) = , E(F) =  Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c More than One Factor? m factor orthogonal model (ORTHOGONAL=INDEPENDENT) Example: fragility has domains, including strength, flexibility, speed Same general assumptions as one factor model: corr(Fs,xj) = Î»js m factors and n observed variables Factor Matrix Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Factor Matrix Cols=derived factors Rows=input variables Loadings (Î») represent degree to which each of the variables â€œcorrelatesâ€ with each of the factors \uf0d8Loadings range from - to  \uf0d8Inspection of factor loadings reveals extent to which each of the variables contributes to the meaning of each of the factors \uf0d8High loadings provide meaning and interpretation of factors (like regression coefficients) Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Factor Analysis Frailty Example Factors Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Variance Explained by Common Factors: Communalities The communality of Xj is the proportion of the variance of Xj explained by the m common factors: \uf0d8Recall one factor model: what was the interpretation of Î»j? â€¦ communality of Xj \uf0d8In other words, it can be thought of as the sum of squared multiple-correlation coefficients between the Xj and the factors Uniqueness(Xj) =  -Comm(Xj) Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Communality of Xj â€œCommonâ€ = part of variance, \uf0d8covariance between Xj and the part of Xj due to the underlying factors â€“ For standardized Xj : â€¢  = communality + uniqueness â€¢ uniqueness =  â€“communality â€“ one Can think of uniqueness = var(ej) If Xj is informative, communality is high If Xj is notinformative, uniqueness is high \uf0d8Intuitively: variables with high communality share more in common with the rest of the variables Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c How many factors? \uf0d8Intuitively: The number of uncorrelated constructs that are jointly measured by the Xâ€™s \uf0d8Only useful if number of factors is less than number of Xâ€™s (recall â€œdata reductionâ€) \uf0d8Identifiability: Is there enough information in the data to estimate all of the parameters in the factor analysis? May be constrained to a certain number of factors Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Choosing Number of Factors Use â€œprincipal components analysis (PCA)â€ to help decide: \uf0d8type of factor analysis \uf0d8number of factors is equivalent to number of variables \uf0d8each factor is a weighted combination of the input variables Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Eigenvalues To select how many factors to use, consider eigenvalues from a principal components analysis â€¢Two interpretations: \uf0d8Eigenvalue â‰… equivalent number of variables which the factor represents \uf0d8Eigenvalue â‰… amount of variance in the data described by the factor â€¢Rules to go by: \uf0d8number of eigenvalues>  \uf0d8Screeplot \uf0d8% variance explained \uf0d8comprehensibility Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Principal Components Frailty Example Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Scree Plot Frailty Example Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c First  factors in principal components Frailty Example Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c At this stageâ€¦ Main concern: whether a smaller number of factors can account for variability in order to: \uf0d8provide number of common factors to be extracted \uf0d8provide objective criterion for choosing number of factors (eg screeplot, % variability, etc) Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Rotation In PCA, the first factor describes most of variability \uf0d8After choosing number of factors to retain, we want to spread variability more evenly among factors \uf0d8To do this we â€œrotateâ€ factors: â€“redefine factors such that loadings on various factors tend to be very high (- or ) or very low () â€“intuitively, it makes sharper distinctions in the meanings of the factors â€“We use â€œfactor analysisâ€ for rotation NOT principal components! Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c  Factors, Unrotated Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c  Factors, Rotated Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c  Factors, Unrotated Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c  Factors, Rotated Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Rotating Factors (Intuitively) Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Orthogonal vs Oblique Rotation Orthogonal: Factors are independent \uf0d8varimax: maximize squared loading variance across variables (sum over factors) \uf0d8quartimax: maximize squared loading variance across factors (sum over variables) â€“Intuition: from previous picture, there is a right angle between axes â€¢Note: â€œUniquenessesâ€ remain the same! Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Orthogonal vs Oblique Rotation Oblique: Factors not independent Change in â€œangleâ€ \uf0d8oblimin: minimize squared loading covariance between factors \uf0d8promax: simplify orthogonal rotation by making small loadings even closer to zero â€“Intuition: from previous picture, angle between axes is not necessarily a right angle â€¢Note: â€œUniquenessesâ€ remain the same! Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Promax Rotation:  Factors Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Promax Rotation:  Factors Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c  Factor, Varimax Rotated Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c  Factor, Varimax Rotated Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Which to use? Drop variables with Uniqueness> in  factor model Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c Some remarks at the end! Doing quantitative research, the design of controlled experiments is a non-trivial exercise! MORE MIND! \uf0d8You may have measurement error problems \uf0d8You will need to make assumptions about how things are related to determine inference \uf0d8You may have incomplete/imprecise data \uf0d8Target causal quantity of interest may not be well defined \uf0d8Confounding variables A confounder is a variable that influences both the dependent variable and independent variable, causing a spurious association \uf0d8Selection bias (self-selection, truncated samples) \uf0d8Measurement error (that can induce confounding, not only noise) \uf0d8Misspecification (eg, wrong functional form) \uf0d8External validity problems (wrong inference to target population) Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c QUESTIONs? Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c References Richardson, H A, Simmering, M J, and Sturman, M C  â€œA Tale of Three Perspectives: Examining Post Hoc Statistical Techniques for Detection and Correction of Common Method Variance,â€ Organizational Research Methods(:), pp - Practical Statistics for Data Scientists:  Essential Concepts st Edition, Peter Bruce, Andrew Bruce Holland, Paul W () "Statistics and Causal Inference" J Amer Statist Assoc  (): â€“ doi:/ Rubin, Donald () "Causal Inference Using Potential Outcomes" J Amer Statist Assoc  (): â€“ doi:/ Bartholomew, DJ; Steele, F; Galbraith, J; Moustaki, I () Analysis of Multivariate Social Science Data Statistics in the Social and Behavioral Sciences Series (nd ed) Taylor & Francis ISBN - Child, Dennis (), The Essentials of Factor Analysis (rd ed), Continuum International, ISBN ---- Courtney, M G R () Determining the number of factors to retain in EFA: Using the SPSS R-Menu v to make more judicious estimations Practical Assessment, Research and Evaluation, () Available online: http://pareonlinenet/getvnasp?v=&n= Jolliffe IT Principal Component Analysis, Series: Springer Series in Statistics, nd ed, Springer, NY, , XXIX,  p  illus ISBN ---- Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c References Larsen, R; Warne, R T () "Estimating confidence intervals for eigenvalues in exploratory factor analysis" Behavior Research Methods  (): â€“ doi:/BRM Suhr, Diane () "Principal component analysis vs exploratory factor analysis" SUGI  Proceedings Retrieved  April  Quantitative Research Methods  \x0c

filename: A Tale of Three Perspectives_ Examining Post Hoc Statistical Tech.pdf
title: A Tale of Three Perspectives: Examining Post Hoc Statistical Techniques for Detection and Corrections of Common Method Variance
authors: Hettie A. Richardson, Marcia J. Simmering, Michael C. Sturman
topic1: cmv using variance post hoc techniques regarding nature sets assumptions
topic2: within researchers use face concerns statistical among scholars strategies exist
topic3: data three strategy effects across constructs many same-source method although
abstract: Many researchers who use same-source data face concerns about common method variance (CMV) Although post hoc statistical detection and correction techniques for CMV have been proposed, there is a lack of empirical evidence regarding their efficacy Because of disagreement among scholars regarding the likelihood and nature of CMV in self-report data, the current study evaluates three post hoc strategies and the strategy of doing nothing within three sets of assumptions about CMV: that CMV does not exist, that CMV exists and has equal effects across constructs, and that CMV exists and has unequal effects across constructs The implications of using each strategy within each of the three assumptions are examined empirically using , simulated data sets varying factors such as the amount of true variance and the amount and nature of CMV modeled Based on analyses of these data, potential benefits and likely risks of using the different techniques are detailed
keywords: management, common method variance, self-reported affect, leadership, data simulation
category_topics: research, user, study, social, question, design, model, theory, information, qualitative

title: Bridging the Qualitative-Quantitative Divide: Guidelines for Conducting Mixed Methods Research in Information Systems
authors: Viswanath Venkatesh, Susan A. Brown and Hillol Bala
topic1: mixed quantitative work develop guidelines conducting rich phenomena fully method
topic2: approach meta-inferences combines help interest cannot understood notwithstanding benefits systems
topic3: methods research qualitative using inquiry insights various calls dearth information
abstract: Mixed methods research is an approach that combines quantitative and qualitative research methods in the same research inquiry. Such work can help develop rich insights into various phenomena of interest that cannot be fully understood using only a quantitative or a qualitative method . Notwithstanding the benefits and repeated calls for such work, there is a dearth of mixed methods research in information systems. Building on the literature on recent methodological advances in mixed methods research , we develop a set of guidelines for conducting mixed methods research in IS. We particularly elaborate on three important aspects of conducting mixed methods research: (1) appropriateness of a mixed methods approach ; (2) development of meta-inferences (i.e., substantive theory) from mixed methods research; and (3) assessment of the quality of meta-inferences (i. e. , validation of mixed methods research). The applicability of these guidelines is illustrated using two published IS papers that used mixed methods
keywords: Meta-inferences, mixed methods, multimethod, positivist, qualitative, quantitative, research method, research design, validity
category_topics: research, user, study, social, question, design, model, theory, information, qualitative

filename: Determining the Number of Factors to Retain in EFA_ Using the SPS.pdf
title: Practical Assessment, Research, and Evaluation
topic1: techniques factor common technique question performing retain important lead conclusions
topic2: number factors modern five exploratory utilized instruments estimate retain especially
topic3: analysis efa development assessment key question procedure best estimate number
abstract: Exploratory factor analysis (EFA) is a common technique utilized in the development of assessment instruments. The key question when performing this procedure is how to best estimate the number of factors to retain. This is especially important as under- or over-extraction may lead to erroneous conclusions. Although recent advancements have been made to answer the number of factors question, popular statistical packages do not come standard with these modern techniques. This paper details how to program IBM SPSS Statistics software (SPSS) to conveniently perform five modern techniques designed to estimate the number of factors to retain. By utilizing the five empirically-supported techniques illustrated in this article, researchers will be able to more judiciously model data.
category_topics: research, user, study, social, question, design, model, theory, information, qualitative

abstract: IO\t \tQualitative Research Methods I University of Amsterdam Data Systems Project Michael Kern https://wwwuvanl/binaries/_ht_/medium/content/gallery/subsites/extranet/huisstijl/logo-tagjpg \x0c Introduction https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c The Nature of Qualitative Research â€¢ Constructionist ontology â€¢ the mind is active in the construction of knowledge, as opposed to: knowledge as the correct representation of an independent reality â€“ logical empiricism â€¢ Interpretivist epistemology â€¢ researcher is part of the research and can never be fully objective, as opposed to: looking at data subjectively using statistics and large number of participants â€“ positivism \x0c Definitions â€¢ Qualitative research is a scientific method of observation to gather non - numerical data â€¢ Babbie â€¢ Qualitative research refers to the meanings, concepts definitions, characteristics, metaphors, symbols, and description of things and not to their counts or measures â€¢ Berg et al â€¢ Qualitative research appraoches are employed across many academic desciplines, focusing particularily on the human elements of the social and natural sciences â€¢ Given \x0c Characteristics â€¢ Idiographic (relating to the study or discovery of particular scientific facts and processes, as distinct from general laws) â€¢ Perspective of the respondent central â€¢ Direct observation in natural setting ( \uf0e0 contextual understanding of situations/ phenomena ) â€¢ Researcher as main instrument of data collection ( \uf0e0 reflexive role) â€¢ â€˜Most commonly used for theory developing (observation \uf0e0 theory) â€¢ Iteration of data collection and analysis (emergent design) \x0c Preoccupation â€¢ Seeing through the eyes of those studied â€¢ Understanding the meanings people attribute to their world â€¢ Meaning in context (intelligible context) â€¢ Detailed accounts of the social setting needed â€¢ Emphasis on social process â€¢ How patterns of events unfold over time â€¢ Concepts and theory grounded in the data \x0c Quantitative versus Qualitative Source: http ://wwwpublichealthnotescom/differences - qualitative - quantitative - research/ \x0c Quantitative versus Qualitative \x0c Qualitative Research for Data Science https://miromediumcom/max//*qzHJEIincNUcB Source: Cartoon created by Indeed UX Research Manager Dave Yeats \x0c Qualitative Research for Data Science â€¢ Is important unless no human beings are involved at all â€¢ E specially important for marketing research â€¢ Q uantitative canâ€™t answer Why questions â€¢ M akes quantitative more meaningful and useful \uf0e0 often combined â€¢ N ot using qualitative research can lead to â€¢ N eglecting critical parameters â€¢ N ot emphasizing with the users â€¢ M isinterpreting data \x0c Data Collection and Analysis https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Main Process Steps â€¢ Research starts with single idea and not with a causal relationship of variables \uf0e0 relationships evolve out of the study \x0c Data Collection Characteristics â€¢ Interested in developing concepts & theory in conjunction with data collection â€¢ Avoids premature theory construction â€¢ T echnical concepts used too early in the research \uf0e0 sensitizing role â€¢ S hould be point of reference and a guide rather than predetermining the phenomenon under investigation â€¢ Data analysis simultaneous with data collection â€¢ ongoing process of collection, analysis & theory construction (iterative ) â€¢ The researcher builds abstractions, concepts, hypotheses, and theories from details \x0c Data Collection Interconnectivity \x0c Sampling https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Sampling â€¢ S electing a group or setting (or time or people) from a broader set of choices in such a way that the subset (or the sample) is in some way representative of the broader set â€¢ Sampling is not just about people BUT also about planning â€¢ Time periods need to be sampled if observations are made at different times of the day or on different days of the week â€¢ Contexts need to be sampled if observations are made in different locations â€¢ Documents can be selected for their relevance to research questions \x0c Sampling levels â€¢ Consideration needs to be given to both the case and the units within that case â€¢ Sampling of context â€¢ Deviant case sampling, typical case sampling , etc â€¢ Sampling of participants within that context â€¢ Maximum variation sampling, criterion sampling, theoretical sampling, snowball sampling , etc \x0c Sampling Methods â€¢ Purposive sampling â€¢ Criteria for selecting individuals or cases determined by research questions â€¢ Sampling chosen for a purpose, eg people , times, and settings that are representative of given criteria â€¢ C ases are selected on the basis of their relevance to research questions â€¢ C onvenience Sampling â€¢ Cases are selected on the basis of their ease of access or convenience â€¢ O ften depending on geographic location, required resources, contacts, etc \x0c Sampling Methods â€¢ Snowball sampling â€¢ A small group of people are selected initially, on the basis of research relevance â€¢ Then these participants propose others with similar characteristics or experience â€¢ Can be useful when networks of individuals are the research focus â€¢ Probability Sampling â€¢ Sampling based on theory of probability â€¢ In appropriate for qualitative research \x0c Sampling Size â€¢ Quality over quantity â€¢ Meeting criteria is crucial â€¢ P articipants should be selected based on sutifulness to study â€¢ Consider the study design â€¢ S tudy design and questions influence sample size â€¢ Principle of saturation â€¢ G oal is to reach saturation â€¢ L arger sample size can lead to repetitive data â€¢ Quantiative goal: reduce estimation error Qualitative goal: reduce discovery failure \x0c Data Collection Approaches https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Case Study https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Case Study â€¢ Focuses on a case in its own right (a person, group, a setting, an organisation) â€¢ Study a phenomenon or system in many aspects within and including its context â€¢ a special environment in which a certain theory or framework or intervention can be tested or evaluated â€¢ â€œLessons learnedâ€ is often important goal â€¢ Data Collection Methods : interview, observation, document analysis \x0c Interview â€“ Key Concepts â€¢ Conversation with a purpose â€¢ ( Kahn and Cannell , ) â€¢ Three forms â€¢ Open â€¢ R esearcher follows flow of conversation led by partner â€¢ A ims at: exploration of opinions, attitudes, and/or common knowledge â€¢ Semi - structured â€¢ R esearcher has defined discussion topics but answers are open, â€¢ Aims at: R efinement or check of opinions, attitudes, and/or common knowledge â€¢ Structured â€¢ R esearcher has predefined questions â€¢ Aims at: elicitation of specific data, eg (quantitative ) survey \x0c Interview â€“ Planning and Conducting â€¢ Questions â€¢ Two types of questions â€¢ closed questions have a predetermined answer format, eg â€˜yesâ€™ or â€˜ noâ€™ â€¢ open questions do not have a predetermined format â€¢ Avoid â€¢ Long questions â€¢ Compound sentences - split them into t wo â€¢ Jargon and language that the interviewee may not understand â€¢ Leading questions that make assumptions , eg why do you likeâ€¦? â€¢ Unconscious biases , eg gender stereotypes \x0c Interview â€“ Planning and Conducting â€¢ Interviewer â€¢ Skills â€¢ An enquiring mind â€¢ Good observation (listening, reading, looking) â€¢ Adaptiveness and flexibility â€¢ Interpret and not simply record â€¢ Lack of bias â€¢ Tools â€¢ Recorder (Audio, Video, etc) â€¢ Notebook \x0c Interview â€“ Planning and Conducting â€¢ Procedure Do trial run of interview beforehand Introduction â€¢ i ntroduce yourself, explain the goals of the interview , reassure about the ethical issues, ask to record, present any informed consent for m Warm - up â€¢ m ake first questions easy and non - threatening Main body â€¢ p resent questions in a logical order A cool - off period â€¢ include a few easy questions to defuse tension at the end Closure â€¢ thank interviewee, signal the end, eg , switch recorder off \x0c Interview â€“ Analysis â€¢ Reliability is an issue â€¢ What people say may not be what they do, eg personal interests of interviewee or researcher bias â€¢ Solutions â€¢ Checks and cross - checks ( triangulation ) â€¢ Data triangulation â€¢ Investigator triangulation â€¢ Theory triangulation â€¢ Methodological triangulation â€¢ Environmental triangulation â€¢ Minutes/audiotaping (trace to original evidence) â€¢ Second opinions (interviewees, researchers ) â€¢ â€œ teach back â€ to avoid misunderstandings \x0c Interview â€“ Analysis â€¢ Type of notes â€¢ Structured answers â€¢ Make notes from memory after the interview â€¢ Take minimal notes in the interview and amplify later â€¢ Take verbatim notes during the interview â€¢ Dictate only the relevant information from the tape - recorded interview â€¢ Tape - record the interview and transcribe it all \x0c Documentary https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Documentary â€¢ The study of text, talk and material culture â€¢ Document types: â€¢ public records , the media , private papers , biography & objects \uf0e0 things that we can â€˜readâ€™ and which relate to some aspect of the social world â€¢ socially produced, ie, produced on the basis of certain ideas, theories, or commonly accepted taken - for - granted principles â€¢ Examples â€¢ How texts reveal pra c tical decision making of people in a certain context \uf0e0 files of selection interviews â€¢ Texts as legitimation of activities => records of official proceedings (legal , business meetings , parliamentary committees , etc) â€¢ Data Collection methods : discourse and conversation analysis \x0c Discourse Analysis â€¢ Umbrella term for variety of approaches to study of texts and talk â€¢ F ocuses on â€¢ R hetorical or argumentative organization of texts and talk â€¢ P urposes and effects of different types of language â€¢ C ultural rules and conventions in communication â€¢ H ow values, beliefs, and assumptions are communicated â€¢ H ow language relates to its social, political, and historical context â€¢ Example Research Question â€¢ H ow is the decision to become vegetarian warranted by the s peakers ? \x0c Conversation Analysis â€¢ A pproaches to study social interaction, especialy natural conversation â€¢ Focus es on â€¢ P eopleâ€™s methods for producing orderly social interaction â€¢ S table practices and normative organizations of interaction â€¢ V erban and non - verbal conducat \x0c Ethnography https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Ethnography â€¢ A tool for discovering cultural meaning; the search for the parts of a culture and their relationships as conceptualized by informants â€¢ Spradley , â€¢ A relational theory of meaning: â€¢ Cultural meanings are encoded in symbols â€¢ L anguage is primary symbol system that encodes cultural meaning in every society â€¢ The meaning of any symbol is its relationship to other symbols in a particular culture \x0c Ethnography â€“ Simplified Model â€¢ The task of ethnography is to decode cultural symbols and identify the underlying rules This can be accomplished by discovering the relationships among cultural symbols â€¢ Proceeds by â€¢ examining some phenomenon â€¢ dividing it into its constituent parts â€¢ identifying the relationships among the parts â€¢ and their relationship to the whole â€¢ Requires constant feedback from one stage to another ( problem \uf0e0 hypotheses \uf0e0 collecting data \uf0e0 analyzing data \uf0e0 writing up results) \x0c Ethnography â€“ Sampling â€¢ Often a combination of convenience and snowball sampling â€¢ May involve purposive sampling â€¢ R esearch has to gather information from whoever is prepared to give divulge it â€¢ Stratified sampling might be possible â€¢ Not just people â€¢ S ampling time units (observing at different times) â€¢ Sampling contexts (observe in different locations) \x0c Ethnography â€¢ Focus es on â€¢ T he description and interpretation of the culture and structure of a social group â€¢ Aim: the cultivation of insider knowledge â€¢ Data Collection Methods : participant observation, frequent and often informal interviews \x0c (Participant) Observation â€¢ Prolonged engagement ( immersion ) â€¢ Study people and their behavior in their natural setting â€¢ What people say they do (interview) vs what people actually do (observation) â€¢ Degree of participation: â€˜outsiderâ€™ to â€˜ insiderâ€™ â€¢ Nowadays well established method for organization research as well as technical fields (eg usability, evaluation , design) \x0c (Participant) Observation â€¢ Example R esearch Q uestion â€¢ What are the coordination mechanisms in telepresence interaction? How do they differ from FF interaction ? â€¢ R esponse to limitations of traditional usability studies ( focus on quality of transmission, ease of use , etc ) â€¢ For group interaction instead of focus on one to one â€¢ Focus on meanings in context \x0c Analytical Induction https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Analytical Induction â€¢ Formal qualitative method for building up causal explanations of phenomena from a close examination of cases â€¢ A pproach to the analysis of data in which the researcher seeks universal explanations of phenomena by pursuing the collection of data until no cases are inconsistent with a hypothetical explanation (deviant or negative cases) of a phenomenon are found â€¢ Bryman , \x0c Analytical Induction â€“ Simplified Model â€¢ Look at event and develop a hypothetical statement of what happened â€¢ Then look at another similar event and see if it fits the hypothesis If it doesn\'t, revise hypothesis â€¢ Begin looking for exceptions to hypothesis, when found, revise hypothesis to fit all examples encountered â€¢ Eventually a hypothesis is developed that accounts for a ll observed cases \x0c Analytical Induction â€“ Main Process Rough definition of r esearch question Hypothetical explanation Data collection (examination of cases ) If any deviant cases found , redefine or reformulate hypothesis Continue until all cases fit hypothesis \x0c Grounded Theory https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Grounded Theory â€¢ An approach to generating theory from data â€¢ Data collection and analysis are done hand - in - hand, with constant checking back and forth â€¢ Particularly useful in novel research areas, where the theoretical approach is not clear or non - existent â€¢ Systematic data analysis procedures â€¢ Aim : developing concepts \x0c Grounded Theory â€¢ Theory is derived from the data, which is systematically gathered and analyzed â€¢ Wants to understand peopleâ€™s experiences in as rigorous and detailed a manner as possible â€¢ Iterative process â€¢ Collect verbatim transcripts of interviews and read through a small sample of text ( line - by - line) â€¢ Identify categories and concepts that emerge from the data (text) and link these concepts into theories \x0c Grounded Theory â€“ Sampling and Coding â€¢ Theoretical sampling: Going back to the field to gather specific data to fill gaps within categories and to discover variation within and between them â€¢ Charmaz and Mitchell, â€¢ Coding â€¢ Begins during initial stages of research â€¢ Important first step in generating theory â€¢ Theoretical saturation â€¢ No more codes in novel data being collected \x0c Grounded Theory - Memoing â€¢ Memoing : recording relationships among themes â€¢ Code notes â€¢ describes the concepts that are being discovered â€¢ Theory notes â€¢ summarize researcherâ€™s ideas about what is going on in the text â€¢ after some coding : include research questions raised by the codes â€¢ Operational notes â€¢ about practical matters \x0c Grounded Theory â€“ Constant Comparison â€¢ Constant comparison â€¢ When, why, and under what conditions do these themes occur in the text ? â€¢ Look at transcripts â€¢ Look for indicators of categories in events and behavior \uf0e0 name them and code them on document â€¢ Memo on the comparisons and emerging categories â€¢ Eventually a category saturates when no new codes related to it are formed â€¢ Eventually certain categories become more central focus \uf0e0 axial categories and perhaps even core category \x0c Grounded Theory â€“ Simplified Model â€¢ Careful line - by - line reading of the text while looking for processes, actions , assumptions, and consequences An initial attempt to develop categories which illuminate the data An attempt to saturate these categories with many appropriate cases in order to demonstrate their relevance Developing these categories into more general analytic frameworks with relevance outside the setting \x0c Grounded Theory - Outcome â€¢ Memos â€¢ Concepts (produced by open coding) â€¢ Categories (higher level of abstraction) â€¢ Core categories â€¢ Properties (attributes of a category) â€¢ Hypotheses (initial hunches) â€¢ Theory (Explanation of relationship between concepts) â€¢ Substantive theory (substantive domain; comparisons between cases in one domain) â€¢ Formal theory ( conceptual or analytic domain; comparisons between different domains; extension of substantive theory ) \x0c Grounded Theory â€“ Outcome \x0c Data Collection Decisions â€¢ What people say â€“ interview ( notes, audio / video) â€¢ What people do â€“ observation (notes, video) â€¢ What people write â€“ discourse analysis ( text) â€¢ Appropriateness â€¢ This is of utmost importance for the data collection â€¢ Relates to the nature of the topic of research \uf0e0 W hat kind information is needed to answer my RQ ? \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ The search for patterns in data and for ideas that help explain why those patterns are there in the first place â€¢ Bernard , â€¢ General Guidelines for Qualitative Data Analysis â€¢ Conduct simultaneously with data collection â€¢ Start from day NOT after all data gathered â€¢ Where appropriate start transcribing â€¢ In all cases, start reviewing data in light of your research questions , eg do previous findings apply to my data? If not, why not? â€¢ Set a small task first â€¢ Donâ€™t over - theorize early in the data analysis Instead, begin from a situation or a piece of data and then build theories out of this limited material \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Differnt kinds of data â€¢ S ituations, contexts, phenomena reported in words and pictures â€¢ E veryday language of respondents or technical language of researcher â€¢ I nterview transcripts, participant observation field notes, journals, documents, literature, photographs, video, websites, e - mail correspondence, chat conversations, blogs, etc \x0c D ata Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ H ow do we get from words to data analysis? data reduction â€¢ the process of selecting, focusing, simplifying, abstracting , and transforming â€œ rawâ€ data data display â€¢ an organized assembly of information that permits conclusion drawing and action taking â€¢ m atrices , graphs, networks , and charts which clarify the main direction of your analysis c onclusion drawing/ making inferences â€¢ beginning to decide what things mean, noting regularities, patterns, explanations, etc verification â€¢ testing the provisional conclusions for their plausibility, their confirmability â€“ their validity \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Analysis â€¢ To analyse means to break down into its components or constituents parts â€¢ T hrough reassembly of the parts, one comes to understand the integrity of the whole â€¢ The qualitative analyst breaks down the whole corpus of data by categorizing and coding its segments and then tries to establish a pattern for the whole by relating the codes or categories to one another â€¢ Schwandt , â€¢ During the whole process: writing /memoing (making sense of your data ) \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Memoing â€¢ A ct of writing memos to yourself (or other researchers) during research â€¢ U sually consist of reflection on data collection, outliers in the data, etc â€¢ If you have constructed several major categories, themes, concepts , or theories from your data, start writing about them one at a time â€¢ Note â€¢ numeric frequency of data related to a code, category, theme , concept is not necessarily a reliable indicator of its importance or significance of the item \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Data Reduction Coding â€¢ C oding procedure used to reduce the information to categories or themes â€¢ Codes â€¢ most often a word or a short phrase that symbolically assigns a summative, salient, essence capturing, and/or evocative attribute for a portion of language - based or visual data â€¢ mnemonic devices used to identify or mark the specific themes in a text \uf0e0 designed to help the memory â€¢ a ct as tags to mark off text in a corpus for later retrieval \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Coding â€¢ Breaking data down into manageable segments & naming those segments â€“ word , phrases, whole excerpts â€¢ C oding is linking \uf0e0 It leads you from data to ideas â€¢ G oes hand in hand with memoing about your codes , categories , and themesCoding is analysis â€¢ Miles and Huberman, â€¢ I mportant starting point of most forms of qualitative data analysis ( also referred to as indexing) \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Coding depends heavily on the data â€¢ W hicht type of medium is being coded? The "Multimedia Browser" window Source: https ://wwwmaxqdacom/help - max/ - coding/coding - video \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Considerations for developing codes â€¢ What are main units in your data and how do they relate to one another ? â€¢ Which categories are actually used by the people you are studying? â€¢ Of what general category is this item of data an instance ? â€¢ What does this item of data represent ? â€¢ What is this item of data about ? â€¢ Of what topic is this item of data an instance ? â€¢ W hat is happening here ? â€¢ What are people doing ? â€¢ What do people say they are doing ? â€¢ What kind of event is going on ? \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Coding Process Code as soon as possible Read through your initial set of transcripts Do it again ! Review your codes Consider more general theoretical ideas in relation to codes and data Any one item or slice of data can be coded in more than one way Do not worry about generating what seem to be too many codes \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Different types of code â€¢ Open / initial coding â€¢ F irst cicle, open - ended approach to coding â€¢ In - Vivo coding â€¢ D ata rooted in the language of the participant â€¢ I dentifying the categories and terms used by participants â€¢ R ender explicit conditions, interactions, tactics, and consequences that are implicit to it \uf0e0 understand what it means in a specific context â€¢ Process coding â€¢ W ords and phrases that capture action In-Vivo_ENG Source: https ://wwwmaxqdacom/tip - of - the - month - in - vivo - coding - out - of - the - document \x0c D ata Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ From codes to categories to themes to theory Source: Saldana () The Coding Manual for Qualitative Researchers \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Ryan and Bernard () recommend looking for : â€¢ Repetitions â€¢ Indigenous typologies â€¢ Metaphors and analogies â€¢ Similarities and differences â€¢ Linguistic connectors (â€˜becauseâ€™ and â€˜since â€™, indicating causal connections ) â€¢ Missing data (reflect on what is not in the data ) â€¢ Theory - related material (concepts as springboard for themes ) \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Types of theories â€¢ Thematic analysis: categories of things â€¢ Reasons for gambling â€¢ Sources of debt advice â€¢ Attitudes to the environment â€¢ Typologies : categories of people or processes â€¢ Types of gamblers â€¢ Types of school programmes â€¢ Grant application processes â€¢ Explanatory analysis: why people do or think what they do â€¢ Factors influencing how people feel about income in retirement â€¢ What helps achieve positive outcome from an employment programm \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Coding is a subjective process â€¢ It is not only your approach to qualitative inquiry and ontological , epistemological, and methodological issues that influence and affect your coding decisions â€¢ Creswell , â€¢ All coding is a judgment call since we bring our subjectivities, our personalities and our predispositions to the process â€¢ Sipe and Ghiso , \x0c Data Reduction Coding and Analysis â€¢ Problems with coding â€¢ Coding results in fragmentation of data \uf0e0 narrative flow of what people say is lost â€¢ Losing the context of what is said \uf0e0 may loose social setting â€¢ Be careful with the text snippets that you select with the code â€¢ important for comparing codes \x0c Tools https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Tools â€¢ Common Qualitative Data Analysis Software includes â€¢ MAXQDA ( mixed methods ) â€¢ https://wwwmaxqdacom/ â€¢ QDA MINER â€¢ https://provalisresearchcom/products/qualitative - data - analysis - software/ â€¢ ATLASti â€¢ https://atlasticom/ â€¢ Dedoose ( mixed methods ) â€¢ https://wwwdedoosecom/ â€¢ Nvivo â€¢ https://wwwqsrinternationalcom/nvivo/nvivo - products \x0c Criticism https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Criticism â€¢ Too subjective â€¢ Researcher as main data collection instrument â€¢ Difficult to replicate â€¢ Unstructured format â€¢ Problems of generalization â€¢ Samples not â€˜representativeâ€™ of all cases â€¢ Lack of transparency â€¢ Often unclear what researcher actually did \x0c Qualitative Research Methods I â€“ Summary https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Qualitative Research Methods I - Summary â€¢ Characteristics â€¢ Idiographic, contextual, iterative â€¢ R esearcher is the instrument of data collection â€¢ Data Collection and Analysis â€¢ Many approches, including â€¢ Case Study (studies a phenomen in its context, eg interviews) â€¢ Documentary (studies documents with social aspects, eg discourse analysis) â€¢ Ethnography (studies cultural meaning, eg P articipant observation) â€¢ Analytical induction (studies cases and adapts hypothesis until it includes all cases) â€¢ Grounded Theory (studies categories, concepts, and themes in data to derive a theory) â€¢ Data and data dollection methods are interconnected â€¢ Research approach has to be appropriate for research question \x0c Qualitative Research I â€“ Summary â€¢ Sampling â€¢ Selecting individuals, cases, or groups to represent the broader set â€¢ Many methods, including â€¢ Purposive sampling (selection based on relevance to research question) â€¢ Convenience sampling (selection based on ease - of - access) â€¢ Snowball sampling (selection based on other selected individuals) â€¢ Probability sampling (random sampling, not suitable for qualitative research) â€¢ Coding â€¢ Assign codes to snippets of text that summarize, capture, or eveoke attributes â€¢ R educed data to categories and themes â€¢ Is a subjective process and can lead to loss of context \x0c Thank you for your attention https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Sources â€¢ Babbie , Earl () The Basics of Social Research (th ed) Belmont, California: Wadsworth Cengage pp â€“ â€¢ Berg, Bruce Lawrence; Lune, Howard () Qualitative Research Methods for the Social Sciences (th ed) Boston p â€¢ Blaikie , N () Designing Social Research: The Logic of Anticipation â€¢ Given, L M, ed () The Sage Encyclopedia of Qualitative Research Methods SAGE Publications â€¢ Bernard, H R () Research methods in anthropology: Qualitative and quantitative approaches Walnut Creek, CA: AltaMira Press â€¢ Bryman () Social Research Methods Oxford University Press â€¢ Charmaz , C and Mitchell, RD () Grounded Theory in Ethnography, in P Atkinson (ed), Handbook of Ethnography, p - â€¢ Creswell , J W () Qualitative inquiry and research design: Choosing among approaches (nd ed) Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage â€¢ Fischer, M, Kortendick , O and D Zeilyin () The APFT Content Code System: Manual and Software Accessed at: http :// lucyukcacuk/Rainforest/accshtml â€¢ Glaser, B G and Strauss, A L () Generating Theory, in The Discovery of Grounded Theory, Strategies for Qualitative Research , p - Chicago: Aldine Pub Co â€¢ Kahn R and Cannell , C () The Dynamics of Interviewing John Wiley & Sons, New York â€¢ Mason,] () Qualitative researching (nd ed) London: Sage â€¢ Merriam, S B () Qualitative research and case study applications in education San Francisco: Jossey - abstract: IO\t \tQualitative Research Methods II University of Amsterdam Data Systems Project Michael Kern https://wwwuvanl/binaries/_ht_/medium/content/gallery/subsites/extranet/huisstijl/logo-tagjpg \x0c Introduction https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Recap: Qualitative and Quantitative Research â€¢ Qualitative Research â€¢ U nstructured data â€¢ Emerging research design â€¢ Researcher is data gathering instrument â€¢ Rich, deep, variable, explorative â€¢ Tries to understand people in context \uf0e0 Asks a question â€¢ Quantitative Research â€¢ Structured data â€¢ Rigid research design â€¢ Researcher uses questionnaires, tests, equipment, etc, to gather data â€¢ N arrow, focused, highly controlled â€¢ Tries to meassure performances \uf0e0 Tests a hypothesis \x0c Qualitative or Quantitative Questions? What website has the fastest checkout procedure? What is important to users when buying a car? Which parameters achieve the highest accuracy with model A ? Is interface A or B the best? \x0c People and Technology â€“ Human Computer Interaction â€¢ Human Computer Interaction (HCI) â€¢ M ultidisciplinary field of study on the interaction between humans and computers â€¢ Concerned with three â€˜useâ€™ words â€¢ Useful â€¢ F unctional, does things â€¢ Usable â€¢ E asy to do things, does the right things, enjoyable â€¢ Used â€¢ A ttractive, available, acceptable to organization https://public-mediainteraction-designorg/images/uploads/dbadaacefdaffbjpeg \x0c People and Technology â€“ User Experience â€¢ User Experience (UX) â€¢ Part of HCI â€¢ G oes beyond user interface (UI) â€¢ Captures whole experience that is connected to system â€¢ Considers attributes like â€¢ Useful â€¢ U sable â€¢ Desirable â€¢ Findable â€¢ Accessible â€¢ Credible â€¢ V aluable overview \x0c People and Technology â€“ Usability â€¢ Usability â€¢ Part of UX â€¢ â€œT he extent to which a product can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals with effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction in a specified context of use â€ â€¢ ISO - â€¢ quality components â€¢ Learnability â€¢ Efficiency â€¢ Memorability â€¢ Errors â€¢ Satisfaction overview \x0c Why is UX important? Insurance booking page with the sentence 'don't insure me' embedded in a dropdown of countries \x0c Why is UX important? Netflix screen with 'House of Cards' autoplaying \x0c Why is UX important? Juicero phone application displayed on an iPhone next to a glass of juice \x0c Qualitative Research in HCI https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Formative or Summative? â€¢ Formative Research â€¢ B efore production or distribution â€¢ S upports decision making â€¢ P rovides insight into user, goals, problems â€¢ Often qualitative (why and how?) â€¢ Summative Research â€¢ A fter production or distribution â€¢ Supports quality assessment â€¢ Provides insight into acceptance, problems â€¢ Often quantitative (how many or how much?) https://usabilitygeekcom/wp-content/uploads///-xjpg \x0c Usability Testing â€¢ T esting how easy to use a system is by testing with real users â€¢ Most commonly used and crucial UX testing method â€¢ Basic usability study Recruit representative users Give them representative tasks to perform Observe users and note where they encounter problems \x0c Usability Testing â€¢ Basic usability study Recruit representative users â€¢ T ypically users (eg customers) or employees that are not involved in development â€¢ Incentives can be used to motivate participants â€¢ Testing with users is enough to discover % of the usability problems â€¢ Jakob Nielsen, â€¢ More users if there are distinct target groups ( - users per target group) Increase in proportion of usability problems found by number of test users \x0c Usability Testing â€¢ Basic usability study Recruit representative users Give them representative tasks to perform â€¢ M ost important things that users must be able to accomplish â€¢ For each task give the users a task scenario \uf0e0 provides context â€¢ Tasks must Be realistic Be actionable Avoid giving clues and describing the steps â€¢ Good example â€¢ You're planning a vacation to New York City, March âˆ’ March You need to buy both airfare and hotel Go to the American Airlines site and jetBlue Airlines site and see who has the best deals \x0c Usability Testing â€¢ Basic usability study Recruit representative users Give them representative tasks to perform Observe users and note where they encounter problems â€¢ Record reactions and feedback from the user â€¢ Define optimal path and compare with userâ€™s path â€¢ Connect reactions of user to steps or elements â€¢ Donâ€™t interrupt user or give tips â€¢ Communicate with user only if necessary â€¢ U ser needs an answer vs rhetorical â€¢ C omment was inconclusive vs can be derived â€¢ B enefit from further questions vs enough information â€¢ When you communicate use Echo, Boomerang, Columbo https://uploadwikimediaorg/wikipedia/commons/thumb///Maze_simplesvg/px-Maze_simplesvgpng \x0c U sability Testing â€¢ Types of Usability Testing â€¢ Comparative Usability Testing â€¢ Q ualitative comparison of two systems \uf0e0 NOT (quantitative) A/B Testing â€¢ U sed to inform decision making in early stage â€¢ C ompare different design solutions or compare with competitor â€¢ Advantages â€¢ Quality of feedback is increased due to having a point of reference â€¢ E valuation is easier because data can be compared â€¢ P revents settling on design decision prematurely Image result for comparison \x0c U sability Testing â€¢ Types of Usability Testing â€¢ Explorative Usability Testing (User Requirements Capture) â€¢ T esting different services to complete a task â€¢ U sed to find required content and functionality â€¢ Highlights problems and gaps in existing solutions â€¢ Advantages â€¢ Shows user expectations for system â€¢ Users evaluate existing functionality â€¢ P revents wasting effort on unnecessary design decision Image result for exploratory \x0c U sability Testing â€¢ Types of Usability Testing â€¢ Quantitative Usability Testing â€¢ M ostly used summatively \uf0e0 evaluates usability of existing system â€¢ Mostly used remotely â€¢ Benchmark with competitors â€¢ C ompute Return on Investment (ROI), Click - Through Rate (CTR), Time - Based Efficiency, etc â€¢ Examples â€¢ A/B Testing â€¢ System Usability Scale (SUS) â€¢ item questionnaire with - point Likert scale â€¢ Software Usability Measurement Inventory (SUMI) â€¢ item questionnaire with - point Likert scale Image result for system usability scale \x0c Usability Testing â€¢ Benefits â€¢ Direct â€¢ F eedback directly from target group â€¢ G uiding â€¢ R esolves internal discussions by testing â€¢ S afety check â€¢ Discover issues and problems before launch â€¢ G ood for business â€¢ M inimises risk of product failing â€¢ I ncreases likelyhood of usage and reusage â€¢ Downsides â€¢ Test scenario â€¢ L ab setting not % representative â€¢ S cale â€¢ No large samples of feedback \x0c Thinking Aloud â€¢ â€œThe single most valuable usability engineering methodâ€ â€¢ Jakob Nielsen, â€¢ Participants use system while thinking out loud \uf0e0 verbalizing their thoughts â€¢ Basic Thinking Aloud usability study Recruit representative users Give them representative task to perform Shut up and let the users do the talking Observe what users say and do, and where they encounter problems ? \x0c Thinking Aloud â€¢ Benefits â€¢ C heap â€¢ N o special equipment needed â€¢ R obust â€¢ V ery difficult to produce unreliable results â€¢ F lexible â€¢ C an be used for variety of scenarios â€¢ C onvincing â€¢ D irect exposure to thoughts of actual users â€¢ E asy to learn â€¢ I ntuitive research set - up â€¢ Downsides â€¢ Unnatural situation â€¢ D ifficult to keep up monologue â€¢ Filtered statements â€¢ U sers think too much before talking â€¢ Biasing user behaviour â€¢ A ny interruption can cause bias â€¢ Not a solution for everything â€¢ S erves many purposes but not all \x0c how eye tracking works - step by step Eye Tracking â€¢ Tracks and shows where a participant is looking â€¢ Focuses on pupil and determines direction and concentration of gaze â€¢ Answers questions like â€¢ W here is the participant looking? â€¢ H ow long is the participant looking? â€¢ How does the focus move from item to item? â€¢ What parts are being missed? â€¢ Which parts receive more attention? \x0c Eye Tracking â€¢ Projects eye movement onto UI as gazeplots, gaze replays, or heat maps https://medianngroupcom/media/editor////gazeplot-bluewaterspa-botoxinjectablepricing-watermark--png https://medianngroupcom/media/editor////heatmap-humira-ppts-radiuspx-watermark--png screenshot showing saccade pathways \x0c Eye Tracking â€¢ Benefits â€¢ I nobtrusive â€¢ Doesnâ€™t influence interaction â€¢ F lexible â€¢ C an be used for variety of scenarios â€¢ Accurate â€¢ S pecific elements can be focused on â€¢ Unfiltered â€¢ Captures spontaneous movement â€¢ Downsides â€¢ Uncertainty about consciousness â€¢ I gnores empty stares and peripheral vision â€¢ No reasoning â€¢ L acks why participant looked at something â€¢ Potentially expensive â€¢ S pecial equipment necessary \x0c Card Sorting â€¢ U sed to generate/evaluate information architecture (IA), workflow, menu, etc â€¢ U sers receive labeled cards and organize them into groups â€¢ Basic Card Sorting study Recruit representative users Provide them with labeled cards Ask them to group cards as appropriate I dentify trends and categories \x0c Card Sorting â€¢ Types of Card Sorting â€¢ Open Card Sorting â€¢ U sers group cards and name the newly created categories â€¢ U sed for new information architectures â€¢ Closed Card Sorting â€¢ Users place cards in predefined categories â€¢ U sed when adding new information to existing IA â€¢ Remote Card Sorting â€¢ Users group cards online by themselves â€¢ No reasining behind card arrangement â€¢ Face - to - Face Card Sorting â€¢ Users sord cards while being observed â€¢ Thinking Aloud for reasoning and thoughts of users Image result for card sorting ux \x0c Card Sorting â€¢ Benefits â€¢ C heap â€¢ N o special equipment needed â€¢ Q uick â€¢ Time until results is very small (especially if done remotely) â€¢ C onvincing â€¢ D irect insights from users on IA â€¢ S imple â€¢ I ntuitive research set - up â€¢ Downsides â€¢ Unreliable â€¢ R esults can vary or have no pattern â€¢ Time consuming analysis â€¢ D epending on complexity of data â€¢ Discrepancy with goals and tasks â€¢ Resulting IA does not consider user goals \x0c Expert Review â€¢ Reviewers (UX experts) examine the system to identify usability problems â€¢ Usually done when budgets and timescallows donâ€™t allow to involve users â€¢ Reviewers should not be involved in project but external experts â€¢ Basic Expert Review study Find suitable reviewers Let reviewers examine the system D iscuss findings, problems, and recommendations Illustration depicting a group asking an outside individual \x0c Expert Review â€¢ Basic Expert Review study Find suitable reviewers â€¢ Should not be involved in the development or design â€¢ UX experts \uf0e0 extensive experience in doing UX research with real users â€¢ - reviewers discover most usability problems with minimal effort â€¢ Nielsen, Curve of number of usability problems found as more evaluators are added \x0c Expert Review â€¢ Basic Expert Review study Find suitable reviewers Let reviewers examine the system â€¢ Reviewers act like users and navigate through system â€¢ Usually no clear tasks or scenarios â€¢ Reviewers creates document containing â€¢ List of usability strenghts â€¢ L ist of usability problems â€¢ S everety ratings â€¢ R ecommendations â€¢ E xamples of best practices Slide format of an example expert review finding \x0c Expert Review â€¢ Basic Expert Review study Find suitable reviewers Let reviewers examine the system D iscuss findings, problems, and recommendations â€¢ D ocument of expert review should be discussed with team â€¢ Discussion with multiple reviewers beneficial â€¢ Ideally compared to findings of other usability studies â€¢ Settling on actionable items to improve usability \x0c Expert Review â€¢ Types of Expert Review â€¢ Heuristic Evaluation â€¢ Same setup as general expert review â€¢ Design is evaluated based on compliance with heuristics â€¢ Usability Heuristics by Jakob Nielsen â€¢ Web Usability Guidelines by David Travis â€¢ Usability Guidelines by Jakob Nielsen and Don Norman â€¢ A nd many more â€¢ Critique â€¢ Too rigid, doesnâ€™t consider unique context â€¢ G ives false sense of security \x0c Expert Review â€¢ Benefits â€¢ F ast â€¢ UX experts are easier to gather than users â€¢ Low cost â€¢ UX experts only do testing, not other tasks â€¢ Indipendent â€¢ Feedback from an outsider â€¢ Flexible â€¢ C an be used multiple times due to low cost â€¢ Downsides â€¢ Unreliable â€¢ E xperts make assumptions about users â€¢ Not convincing â€¢ Experts are not real users \x0c Qualitative Research Methods II â€“ Summary https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Formative or Summative? Quantitative or Qualitative? https://medianngroupcom/media/editor////quant-vs-qualpng \x0c Qualitative Research Methods II - Summary â€¢ Classic Usability Testing â€¢ Evaluates the ease - of - use of a system by giving real users tasks and observing them â€¢ Comparative Usability Testing â€¢ Is a qualitative comparison of two systems / designs to inform decision making â€¢ Explorative Usability Testing â€¢ Explores different services to complete a task and finds required content and functionality â€¢ Quantitative Usability Testing â€¢ Evaluates a systemâ€™s usability by meassureing predefined metrics and benchmarks \x0c Qualitative Research Methods II - Summary â€¢ Thinking Aloud â€¢ Asks users to verbalize their thoughts while completing a task to gain insight into reasoning â€¢ Eye Tracking â€¢ Tracks eye movement of users to provide insight into attention and cause of problems â€¢ Card Sorting â€¢ Asks users to sort labeled cards to generate or evaluate an information architecture â€¢ Expert Review â€¢ A sks UX experts to inspect system to find usability problems and give recommendations \x0c Thank you for your attention https://wwwbestassignmenthelpcouk/blog/wp-content/uploads///What-is-Qualitative-Research-Methodspng \x0c Sources â€¢ Usability Inspection Methods, , by Jakob Nielsen and Robert L Mack â€¢ The Encyclopedia of Human - Computer Interaction, nd Edition, by Mads Soegaard and Rikke Friis Damn â€¢ The Design of Everyday Things, , by Donald A Norman â€¢ Donâ€™t Make Me Think, Revisited: A Common Sense Approach to Web Usability, , by Steve Krug â€¢ U sability Engineering, , by Jakob Nielsen â€¢ The Elements of User Experience: User - Centered Design for the Web and Beyon (nd Edition), , by Jesse James Garrett â€¢ Eyetracking Web Usability, , by Jakob Nielsen and Kara Pernice â€¢ Interaction Design â€“ Beyond Human - Computer Interaction, th Edition, , by Yvonne Rogers, Jennifer Preece, and Helen Sharp â€¢ Qualitative HCI Research: Going Behind the Scenes, , by Ann Blandford, Dominic Furniss, and Stephann Makri â€¢ Interaction Design Foundation ( https://wwwinteraction - abstract: Research â€“ Why and How Frank Nack (nack@uvanl) Research â€“ Why and How Frank Nack (nack@uvanl) \x0c https://wwwcbrcamacuk/research/ Context Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How https://wwwcbrcamacuk/research/ Context Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c https://wwwcbrcamacuk/research/ Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How Empiricist (Positivist, Realist â€¦) Pragmatist Rationalist Idealist Skeptics Constructivist Naturalized epistemologist Type \x0c https://wwwtrcgovom/trcweb/img/jpg Method Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How https://wwwtrcgovom/trcweb/img/jpg Method Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c https://wwwtescom/lessons/amBoPtxAdFuUw/argumentation Argumentation Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How https://wwwtescom/lessons/amBoPtxAdFuUw/argumentation Argumentation Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Frank Nack (nack@uvanl) http://wwwcityueduhk/youeprj/research/researchhtml Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How Frank Nack (nack@uvanl) http://wwwcityueduhk/youeprj/research/researchhtml Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research -definitions "Any creative systematic activity undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, including knowledge of man, culture and society, and the use of this knowledge to devise new applicationsâ€ OECD () â€Research is a process of steps used to collect and analyze information to increase our understanding of a topic or issue" It consists of three steps: pose a question, collect data to answer the question, and present an answer to the questionâ€ John W Creswell () â€œStudious inquiry or examination; especially : investigation or experimentation aimed at the discovery and interpretation of facts, revision of accepted theories or laws in the light of new facts, or practical application of such new or revised theories or lawsâ€ Merriam Webster () Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Paradigm \x0c Crotty, M () Foundations of social research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process p \x0c Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How  \x0c Research â€“ Design A research design is an overall plan for conducting a research project covering all steps â€“ from raising the research questions through data analysisâ€ (LeComte & Schensul, ) â€¢ Goal (what do you want to achieve, eg solve some problem) â€¢ Decomposition into (researchable, more specific) questions â€¢ How to get the answers: scientific methods (and their proper assembly) Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research â€“ Design Elements â€¢ What the specific issues and research questions related to the problem area â€¢ Why the reasons or rationales for focusing on this area â€¢ Where the place or site where the study can be conducted â€¢ When the time span needed to conduct the study â€¢ How the way in which the information can be located and collected â€¢ Who which people can provide access to the site, people, or sources for information needed to answer the question Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research â€“ Designs https://atsliteacherfileswordpresscom///typesofresearchpng Research by design https://wwwresearchgatenet/publication/_Research_by_Design_Proposition_for_a_Methodological_Approach https://revistasulusofonapt/indexphp/revlae/article/view// Design Thinking https://wwwinteraction-designorg/literature/article/what-is-design-thinking-and-why-is-it-so-popular Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research â€“ Design Process Menken, S and Keestra, M () \x0c Research â€“ Orientation \x0c Identify Problem or Topic Justificationâ€˜ (why?): â€¢Topicnot studied yet â€¢Importanceof events that promote the subject matter (breakthrough events/ technologies) â€¢Appealto current importance â€¢Explicittheoretical interest â€¢Explicitmethodological interest â€¢Outcome=> Research question Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research Question -Criteria Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research Question â€“ Types (Blaikie, ; Robson ) What require a descriptive answer; they are directed towards discovering and describing the characteristics of and patterns in some social phenomenon (eg, information search behavior) Why ask for either the causes of, or the reasons for, the existence of characteristics or regularities in a particular phenomenon They are directed toward understanding or explaining the relationships between events, or within activities and processes How are concerned with bringing about change, with practical outcomes and intervention Answering HOW questions requires a different kind of description which is built on previous answers to both WHAT and WHY questions!!!!! HOW requires a description of a desired state of affairs for getting from an existing situation to the desired situation Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research Question â€“ Types (Blaikie, ; Robson ) Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research Question â€“ Logic of inquiry Top down Bottom up Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research Question â€“ Logic of inquiry Inductive for WHAT; weak on answering WHY questions Deductive and retroductive for WHY Abductive for WHAT and WHY Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research â€“ Literature \x0c Research â€“ Literature Summarize the current state of knowledge in the area of investigation  Empirical state of knowledge: What previous research has been done on this problem?  Theoretical state of knowledge: What are the pertinent theories of the phenomenon? Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research â€“ Literature Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Literature â€“ Gap and contribution Gap Describing the results of other studies that are closely related to the study being reported What do we know already about the topic? Relating the study to the larger, ongoing dialogue in the literature about a topic, filling in gaps and extending prior studies Contribution What are we going to learn as the result of the proposed project that we do not know now yet? Why is it worth knowing? Who will benefit? Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Literature â€“ Review In reviewing previous work, you need not describe every study ever done with which you are dealing A literature review is a synthesis! Emphasize their major conclusions, findings or relevant methodological issues and avoid unnecessary detail Even when you must describe an entire study, try to condense it as much as possible without sacrificing clarity Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Literature â€“ Priorities Begin with the review of recent conference papers on the topic (often report the latest research developments) Look for major conferences and the papers delivered at them (See ACM digital library) Then look at journal articles in respected, scientific journals that report on research studies Start with most recent studies about the topic, then work backward in time Next review books related to the topic Begin with research monographs Then consider entire books that are on a single topic or that contain chapters written by different authors Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Research â€“ Research Method \x0c Methodology Describe methodology â€¢ What will be done to solve the research problem? â€¢ What parts of method are standard, which are innovative â€¢ What will you actually do? Specify sources of data, steps â€¢ Why are tasks outlined best attack on the problem? Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Methodology http://wwwpublichealthnotescom/differences-qualitative-quantitative-research/ Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Methodology https://atsliteacherfileswordpresscom///typesofresearchpng Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Reflection and Conclusion Presenting the findings â€¢ Remind reader about the question(s) asked â€¢ Make argument while presenting empirical data Discussion of and reflection on findings (what do your findings mean? â€¢ Begin by telling reader what you have learnt from the study â€¢ Reflect on findings from already existing theories â€¢ And/or reflection on findings by comparing with other empirical works done by other investigators â€¢ And/or, theory generation Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Future Work How to go from here? â€¢ Based on preliminary findings; how to follow up on them; â€¢ Discussion of questions that remain unanswered or new questions that have been raised by your data and suggestions for kinds of research that would help answer them â€¢ Based on flaws in methodological approach and how to do better in follow-up research â€¢ In order to develop theory further â€¢ making generalizations by comparing across cases; which cases needed and why Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c Summary Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c References Blaikie, N & Priest, J () Designing Social Research: The Logic of Anticipation Polity Blakie, N & Priest, J () Social Research: Paradigms in Action Wiley Bryman () Social Research Methods Oxford University Press Creswell, J W () Educational Research: Planning, conducting, and evaluating quantitative and qualitative research (rd ed) Upper Saddle River: Pearson Crotty, M () Foundations of social research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process LeComte, M and Schensul, J J () Designing & Conducting Ethnographic Research: An Introduction Rowman Altamira Merriam-Webster () Definition Research (https://wwwmerriam-webstercom/) Retrieved:   Menken, S and Keestra, M () An Introduction to Interdisciplinary Research: theory and practice Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press OECD (): OECD Glossary of Statistical Terms - Research and development https://statsoecdorg/glossary/detailasp?ID=, Retrieved:  AL Porter, I Rafols () Is science becoming more interdisciplinary? Measuring and mapping six research fields over time, Scientometrics ():- Robson, C () Real World research â€“ A Resource for Users of Social Research Methods in Applied Settings, rd edition John Wiley and Sons, Ltd Publication Frank Nack Research â€“ Why and How \x0c

abstract: Entrepreneurship for AI and CS Course Manual  / Period  XM_ Coordinator Prof Enno Masurel (coordinator) emasurel@vunl Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam School of Business and Economics Department of Management and Organization Introduction In recent years, academic entrepreneurship education has shifted from the exclusive domains of business administration and economics to many other domains as well In the academic year /, the subject of entrepreneurship was taught for the first time for students of the master Computer Science (joint degree of the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam and the University of Amsterdam) and the master Artificial Intelligence (Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam), in the form of this elective Entrepreneurship for AI and CS (Artificial Intelligence and Computer Science) More than  students joined this elective This elective is only for students from these two masters (and not for students who have already done Entrepreneurship in Data Science and Analytics (EDSA) at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam) Pillars of the course This Entrepreneurship for AI and CS (EAICS) course is based on three pillars: â€ The transfer of academic knowledge in the field of entrepreneurship, during lectures and study of academic papers from renowned international journals and academic books â€ The development of personal entrepreneurial soft skills, which may contribute to entrepreneurial success, during interactive workshops â€ To come from a business idea to a solid business plan, with the help of the adjusted Business Model Canvas  approach and the study of an own real life case Scientific research is not an explicit part of this course, although it is one of the four pillars of academic entrepreneurship education However, scientific research will be dealt with directly and indirectly within all three mentioned pillars of this course Learning objectives After having finished this course successfully, the student is able to: â€ Master the obliged literature on entrepreneurship from the course â€ Critically make use of theoretical foundations for practiceâ€based ideas â€ Think â€˜out of the boxâ€™ concerning entrepreneurial ideas â€ Approach entrepreneurial challenges with extra confidence â€ Develop a business idea according the regular criteria â€ Thoroughly communicate the business plan in a short pitch Examination This course loads six ECs The final grade for this course is based on the written exam and the BMC assignment (both count for %) BMC stands for Business Model Canvas Both forms of examination should be sufficient, ie completed with a grade of at least  The written exam is an individual assignment whereas the BMC assignment is a team assignment (for a team of four students) Next to these obligatory aspects of the course, a number of small assignments have to be delivered, that will be announced during the lectures These small assignments will be assessed with Pass or Fail All three aspects have one option for reâ€sit Presence with all lectures is mandatory, and will be checked Additional to the lectures, two consultancy sessions for each team will be are organized, in which the full teams meet with one of the lecturers, for the further development of their BMC assignments Schedule Below is the abbreviated schedule, which may subject to changes Always check https://roostervunl/ for the most recent and
