kinds of things once we have the annotations linked to an ontology â€¢ We now know that cities can have airports, and people have phone numbers â€¢ Since John is a man, we know he can have a wife â€¢ If we know that the London, where John lives, is in England, we know that Polar Bear Design is also in England and not Ontario University of Sheffield, NLP Ontologies are useful for encoding the information found â€¢ Enable us to define the concepts we're trying to find in texts â€“ eg, aircraft accident, industrial action â€¢ As well as particular instances of these â€“ eg, Qantas flight XYZ crashed on , BA cabin crew were on strike between March -,  â€¢ And the relationships between them â€“ eg, the plane that crashed belonged to Qantas and crashed on a specific date University of Sheffield, NLP Using knowledge from the ontology â€¢ The ontology tells us that â€“ Industrial action involves airport or airline staff and has a start and end date â€¢ It gives a clearly defined schema to annotate against â€“ if you annotate an instance of a strike, then you know this also requires you to annotate the airport/airline affected and the staff on strike â€¢ Extra knowledge about the different kinds of properties and the actors involved can help to improve system performance â€¢ Backbone for other processes, for example visualising results on a timeline University of Sheffield, NLP Text mining and semantic annotation â€¢ Extract structured data from text by â€“ Linking references to entities â€“ Linking entities to their semantic descriptions â€¢ Automatic semantic annotation based on IE technology â€¢ Attaches metadata to documents, which makes them more useful and more easily processable â€¢ They can then be used for searching and hyperlinking, categorising, and monitoring â€¢ Adds value to content of libraries, enabling user interaction with content â€¢ Enhanced capability for cross-referencing and dynamic document classification University of Sheffield, NLP Some Terminology ï¬ Semantic annotation â€“ annotate in the texts all mentions of instances relating to concepts in the ontology ï¬ Ontology learning â€“ automatically derive an ontology from texts ï¬ Ontology population â€“ given an ontology, populate the concepts with instances derived automatically from a text University of Sheffield, NLP Semantic Annotation vs Ontology Population ï¬ Semantic Annotation ï¬ Mentions of instances in the text are annotated wrt concepts (classes) in the ontology ï¬ Requires that instances are disambiguated ï¬ It is the document which is modified ï¬ Ontology Population ï¬ Generates new instances in an ontology from a text ï¬ Links unique mentions of instances in the text to instances of concepts in the ontology ï¬ Instances must be not only disambiguated but also coreference between them must be established ï¬ It is the ontology which is modified University of Sheffield, NLP Semantic Annotation University of Sheffield, NLP Ontology Population University of Sheffield, NLP How to do Semantic Annotation â€¢ Manually: ontology based annotation using OAT (Ontology Annotation Tool) â€¢ Automatically â— Gazetteer/rule/pattern based â— Classifier (ML) based â— Combination of the two University of Sheffield, NLP Manual semantic annotation: OAT â€¢ Shows document and ontology class hierarchy side-by-side â€¢ Interactive creation of annotations that link to the ontology class/instance â€¢ Allows on-the-fly instance creation â€¢ Used to create evaluation or training corpus University of Sheffield, NLP OAT University of Sheffield, NLP Automatic Semantic Annotation in GATE ï¬ GATE supports ontologies as part of IE applications - Ontology-Based IE (OBIE) ï¬ Supports semantic annotation and ontology population ï¬ GATE has its own ontology API based on Sesame  and OWLIM ï¬ Semantic annotation can combine learning and rule-based methods ï¬ Enables use of large-scale linguistic resources for IE, such as WordNet abstract: Controlled Vocabularies Information Organization UvA Paul Groth The Problem of Naming The Vocabulary Problem Term A term is a string of characters that can be used to lexically describe something Controlled Vocabularies â€¢ a dictionary of all possible terms that can be used in a domain for description â€¢ terms + definitions + rules â€¢ authority control http://wwwlocgov/marc/bibliographic/ Knowledge Organization Systems â€¢ Catalog - controlled vocabulary with preferred terms â€¢ Glossary - terms with definitions â€¢ Thesaurus - synonym relationships â€¢ Taxonomy - a controlled vocabulary with all the terms belong to a single parent/child hierarchical structure Schemaorg Becoming Explicit â€¢ Controlled vocabularies allow for easier communication of meaning â€¢ Limit choice â€¢ Increasing structure conveys additional meaning Semantic Models & Ontology Information Organization UvA Paul Groth Semantic Models â€œRepresentation of data whose goal is make the meaning of data explicit and commonly understood among humans and machinesâ€ Panos Alexopoulos Semantic Modeling for Data O'Reilly Media  â€¢ Resource Description Framework (Schema) aka RDF(S) â€¢ Description Logics (eg OWL) a family of formal knowledge representation languages that provide the logical formalisms for Semantic Web languages â€¢ Standards for controlled vocabularies, thesauri, and taxonomies like ANSI/NISO Z, ISO, SKOS â€¢ Lexical databases like WordNet, VerbNet â€¢ Conceptual models for database design (E-R models labeled property graph model for graph databases) Modeling Frameworks Alexopoulos, Panos Semantic Modeling for Data O'Reilly Media Entities A thing with distinct and independent existence (ie resource) Should be unambiguous and distinct within a model Concrete Entity - a thing at a particular place and time Abstract Entity - eg idea, categories, concepts Relations â€¢ Relations express the way that two or more entities can be related to one another Classes â€¢ Classes are abstract entities that represent kinds of things in the world â€¢ Serve as types for other entities â€¢ See Later Discussion of Categorization Attributes â€¢ Represent a characteristic of an entity that we cannot (or choose not to) represent as a relation with another entity â€¢ literal values (ie, numbers, strings, dates, etc) Axioms, Constraints, Rules Features that enable reasoning: Derivation of facts that are not explicitly in the model http://wwwfewvunl/~schlobac/esslli_daypdf Ontology â€¢ â€œAn ontology is a specification of a conceptualizationâ€ - Gruber The Ontology Spectrum Basic Ontology â€¢ Finite controlled (extensible) vocabulary â€¢ Unambiguous interpretation of classes and term relationships â€¢ Strict hierarchical subclass relationships between classes What is Knowledge Representation? What is Knowledge Representation? â€¢ a surrogate â€¢ a set of ontological commitments â€¢ theory of reasoning â€¢ medium for efficient computation â€¢ medium for human expression Semantic Models â€¢ Help us represent knowledge â€¢ Machines People â€¢ Frameworks give us different capabilities for expression â€¢ They share common features Semantic Models In the Wild Information Organization UvA Paul Groth https://developerspotifycom/ documentation/web-api/reference-beta/ #object-albumobject https://labsmlssoccercom/implementing-graphql-at-major-league-soccer-ffabca https://engubercom/uber-eats-query-understanding/ Knowledge Graphs â€¢ Massive collections of metadata about entities in the world â€¢ Graph structured knowledge base

title: HT06, Tagging Paper, Taxonomy, Flickr, Academic Article, To Read
authors: Marlow, Cameron, Mor Naaman, Danah Boyd, and Marc Davis.
topic1: tagging resources social many taxonomy add keywords internet pages images
topic2: systems potential provide enable model possible inform analysis present system
topic3: work help become increasingly users videos relying controlled vocabulary improve
abstract: In recent years, tagging systems have become increasingly popular These systems enable users to add keywords (ie, â€œtagsâ€) to Internet resources (eg, web pages, images, videos) without relying on a controlled vocabulary Tagging systems have the potential to improve search, spam detection, reputation systems, and personal organization while introducing new modalities of social communication and opportunities for data mining This potential is largely due to the social structure that underlies many of the current systems Despite the rapid expansion of applications that support tagging of resources, tagging systems are still not well studied or understood In this paper, we provide a short description of the academic related work to date We offer a model of tagging systems, specifically in the context of web-based systems, to help us illustrate the possible benefits of these tools Since many such systems already exist, we provide a taxonomy of tagging systems to help inform their analysis and design, and thus enable researchers to frame and compare evidence for the sustainability of such systems We also provide a simple taxonomy of incentives and contribution models to inform potential evaluative frameworks While this work does not present comprehensive empirical results, we present a preliminary study of the photosharing and tagging system Flickr to demonstrate our model and explore some of the issues in one sample system This analysis helps us outline and motivate possible future directions of research in tagging systems
keywords: Tagging systems, taxonomy, folksonomy, tagsonomy, Flickr, categorization, classification, social networks, social software, models, incentives, research

abstract: Relationships Paul Groth Information Organization UvA Slides from Robert J Glushko glushko@berkeleyedu @rjglushko Defining "Relationshipâ€œ  â€¢ Relations express the way that two or more entities can be related to one another â€¢ â€œAn association among several things, with that association having a particular significanceâ€ (Kent) â€¢ The reason is an important part of the relationship â€¢ Multiple relationships can exist among the same objects, so the order of the objects matters Five Perspectives on Relationships ()  â€¢ SEMANTIC: the meaning of the association â€¢ LEXICAL: how the conceptual description of a relationship is expressed using words in a specific language â€¢ STRUCTURAL: analyzes the patterns of association, arrangement, proximity, or connection between resources Five Perspectives on Relationships ()  â€¢ ARCHITECTURAL: emphasizes the number and abstraction level of the components of a relationship, which together characterize its complexity â€¢ IMPLEMENTATION: how the relationship is implemented in a particular notation and syntax and the manner in which relationships are arranged and stored in some technology environment Relationships: The Semantic Perspective Paul Groth Information Organization UvA Slides from Robert J Glushko glushko@berkeleyedu @rjglushko The Semantic Perspective on Relationships  â€¢ Critical to understand what relations mean â€¢ Conveys: why the resources are related â€¢ Relies on or expresses information that is not directly available from perception â€¢ â€œHomer is married to Marge" is a semantic assertion; "Homer is standing next to Marge" is not â€¢ It is difficult to define what a relationship means in a non-circular way that doesn't rely on lots of undefined relationshipsâ€¦ Making Sense () Making Sense ()  â€¢ Draw a diagram that represents these assertions: â€¢ "Mary and Sue are sistersâ€œ â€¢ "Sally and Martha are mothersâ€ Mother Mary Sue Mary and Sue are sistersâ€¦ â€¦of each other Maryâ€™s Mother Mary Maryâ€™s Sister Sueâ€™s Mother Sue Sueâ€™s Sister Mary and Sue are sistersâ€¦ â€¦of other people Sally Sallyâ€™s Child Sally and Martha are mothers â€¦of different children Martha Marthaâ€™s Child Sally and Martha are mothers â€¦Sally is Marthaâ€™s mother Sally Martha (Sallyâ€™s Child) Marthaâ€™s Child Language and Meaning  â€¢ Words and sentence structure only hint at meaning â€¢ Meaning is constructed not just from the literal language used, but from all the clues or cues in the context of use -- common knowledge, assumptions, previous discourse, the present situation, and inferences from all of these The Semantics of "Inclusion"  â€¢ One class or type of resources logically contains another; predicate is usually is-a or "is-a-type-of" â€¢ A set of interconnected class inclusion relationships defines a HIERARCHY or TAXONOMY â€¢ An inclusion relationship between an instance and a class -- assigning an instance to a class - is CLASSIFICATION TDO Figure  Part-Whole (Meronymic) Inclusion  â€¢ A resource class or instance can contain another as physical or logical parts â€¢ Expressed using â€œis-part-of,â€ â€œis-partly,â€ or with other similar predicate expressions â€¢ The engine is part of the car â€¢ The book is part of the library â€¢ Wine is partly alcohol â€¢ The Napa Valley is part of Northern California â€¢ Extra time is part of a football match Part-Whole Relationship (Component-Object) Topological, Locative, and Temporal Inclusion  â€¢ A relationship between container, area, or time period and something it surrounds or contains (expressed using â€œis inâ€) â€¢ But unlike part-whole inclusion, the contained thing is not part of the container â€¢ The Vatican City is in Italy â€¢ The meeting is in the afternoon The Semantics of â€œAttributionâ€  â€¢ In contrast to inclusion expressions that state relationships between resources, attribution relationships assert or assign values to properties for a particular resource â€¢ Attribution can be thought of as a binary relationship whose predicate has a single argument: Martin the Gecko => is-small "Title" : "Moby Dickâ€œ â€¢ Or with two arguments: Martin => has-size => small The Semantics of â€œAttributionâ€  â€¢ There are often many different ways of expressing equivalent attribute values â€¢ Martin â†’ has-size â†’  inches â€¢ Martin â†’ has size â†’  mm â€¢ Do these mean the same thing? Properties of Semantic Relationships: Symmetry ()  â€¢ SYMMETRY: the order in which the arguments of a binary relationship doesn't matter Homer Simpson => is-married-to => Marge Simpson Marge Simpson => is-married-to => Homer Simpson Properties of Semantic Relationships: Symmetry ()  â€¢ Relationships that are symmetric are also called BI-DIRECTIONAL â€¢ ASYMMETRIC relationships are those where the order of the arguments matters Homer Simpson => is-parent-of => Bart Simpson Properties of Semantic Relationships: Inverse  â€¢ For asymmetric relationships, it is often useful to be explicit about the meaning of the relationship when the order of the arguments in the relationship is reversed â€¢ The resulting relationship is called the INVERSE or the converse of the first relationship Properties of Semantic Relationships: Transitivity ()  â€¢ TRANSITIVITY: if X and Y have a relationship, and Y and Z have the same relationship, then X also has the relationship with Z Homer Simpson => is-taller-than => Bart Simpson Bart Simpson => is-taller-than => Maggie Simpson IMPLIES THAT Homer Simpson => is-taller-than => Maggie Simpson Properties of Semantic Relationships: Transitivity ()  â€¢ Any relationship based on inclusion or ordering is transitive â€¢ Ordering includes numerical, alphabetic, and chronological relationships as well as those that imply qualitative or quantitative measurement Properties of Semantic Relationships: Equivalence  â€¢ Any relationship that is both symmetric and transitive is an EQUIVALENCE relationship â€¢ We often need to assert that a particular class or property has the same meaning as another class or property or that it is generally substitutable for it Ontology  â€¢ An ontology defines the concepts used to describe and represent some domain or area of knowledge â€¢ To fully understand a domain you need to know class and part-whole inclusion, attribution, equivalence, and many other relationships about and between the resources it contains â€¢ Class inclusion relationships form a kind of backbone or framework to which other kinds of relationships attach, creating a network of relationships Analyzing the Definition of Ontology  â€¢ The word ontology has been used to describe artifacts with different degrees of structure that differ: â€¢ according to how precisely the terms are defined â€¢ according to how precisely the relationships among them are expressed â€¢ So the simplest ontology is a dictionary â€¢ A thesaurus is a somewhat more complex ontology â€¢ More complete ontologies are expressed using formal logic-based language TDO Figure  Relationships: The Lexical Perspective Paul Groth Information Organization UvA Slides from Robert J Glushko glushko@berkeleyedu @rjglushko The Lexical Perspective on Relationships  â€¢ A prototypical word is the minimal "meaning bearing" element of language â€¢ Words express concepts and relationships, but not all concepts and relationships have words for them (are "lexicalized") â€¢ These "lexical gaps" differ from language to language â€¢ Whereas "conceptual gaps" -- the things we can't think of -- may be innate and universal Relationships Among Words / Relationships Among Concepts  â€¢ Representing the relationships among words is a task for linguistics and cognitive science â€¢ In contrast, representing the relationships among concepts is a task for computer science â€¢ Understanding both kinds of relationships is essential for designers of organizing systems Relationships Among Words  â€¢ Hyponymy/Hyperonymy â€¢ Metonymy â€¢ Synonymy â€¢ Polysemy â€¢ Antonymy Hyponymy/Hyperonymy  â€¢ When words encode IS-A or inclusion relationships, the word for the more specific class is the HYPONYM and the other is the HYPERNYM â€¢ So there can be a "lexical hierarchy" that represents the "semantic hierarchy" â€¢ Often used to situate "basic categories" with respect to superordinate and subordinate categories Hyponymy/Hyperonymy  â€¢ A is a hyponym of B if A is a type of B â€¢ A robin is a hyponym of bird â€¢ A is a hypernym of B if B is a type of A â€¢ An animal is a hypernym of bird A Formula for Definitions  hyponym = {adjective+} hypernym {distinguishing clause+} â€¢ Robin = Migratory BIRD with clear melodious song, a reddish breast, gray or black upper plumage â€¢ Doesn't mention every characteristic of hyponym, only those needed to distinguish from other hyponyms Metonymy  â€¢ The lexical representation of or analogy to part-whole or meronymic relationships â€¢ Using one aspect of something to stand for the whole â€¢ "Bank" as building stands for the institution of the "bank" â€¢ "The White House released new budget figures today" Synonymy  â€¢ Synonyms are different word forms that can express the same concept â€¢ cat, feline, Siamese cat â€¢ Absolute synonyms that can always substitute for each other probably don't exist â€¢ Propositional synonyms are those where substituting one for another isnâ€™t likely to change the truth value of the statement Polysemy  â€¢ Many "word forms" (particular spelling patterns) are polysemous with multiple senses established in the language -- they are semantically ambiguous - That dog has floppy ears - She has a good ear for jazz â€¢ "bank" (financial) has related senses: - a building (the bank on Shattuck) - specific financial firm (Wells Fargo) - where money is kept (abstract notion) - where anything of value is kept (more abstract) Polysemy vs Homonymy  â€¢ A HOMOGRAPH is a word with multiple senses that are not conceptually related - bank (financial sense) - bank (river sense) â€¢ But what looks like homography may be polysemy from a historical perspective - mole (an animal that digs holes; an infiltrating spy) â€¢ HOMOPHONES are words with the same pronunciation but different spellings and meanings - to, two, too; might, mite; clawed, claude Antonymy  â€¢ Antonyms are lexical opposites â€¢ Some are inherently binary â€œtrue antonymsâ€ â€¢ dead / alive, true / false, on / off â€¢ Others are "graded" â€¢ long / short, hot / cold â€¢ Markedness: if one member of a pair is more restricted in its contexts it can stand out psychologically â€¢ long is unmarked, short is marked Thesauri  â€¢ A THESAURUS is a tool for finding the "right" or "good" terms of a controlled vocabulary â€¢ It is a collection of vocabulary terms annotated with lexical relationships to indicate terms that are: â€¢ Preferred (UF "used for") â€¢ Broader (BT "broader term") â€¢ Narrower (NT "narrower term") â€¢ Related (RT "related term" or "see also") â€¢ USE in a thesaurus refers the reader from a variant term to a preferred term; the inverse of UF Implications for Vocabulary Design  â€¢ Choosing vocabulary terms, and precisely defining their semantics, is essential but impossible to do perfectly â€¢ Your vocabulary must express what YOU intend, so you "look inward" -- analyze how you think about a domain â€¢ You want others to understand what you mean, so you need to "look outward" -- analyze the terms used by your users, competitors, or subject matter experts â€¢ You should reuse other vocabularies or thesauri if they exist, especially for any "horizontal" components, to improve transformability and interoperability â€¢ But these three approaches may suggest different terms https://wordnetprincetonedu Relationships: The Structural Perspective Paul Groth Information Organization UvA Slides from Robert J Glushko glushko@berkeleyedu @rjglushko The Structural Perspective on Relationships  â€¢ Analyzing the association, arrangement, proximity, or connection between resources without primary concern for their meaning or the origin of these relationships â€¢ Sometimes structure is all we knowand sometimes we ignore what we know about relationship semantics to focus on the generic aspect of structural connectivity Internal and External Structure ()  â€¢ Resources can have INTERNAL structure as well as the EXTERNAL structure that connects them to other resources â€¢ We often make arbitrary decisions about the granularity with which we describe the internal structure of a resource â€¢ The boundaries we impose to identify resources determines whether some structure is internal or external with respect to them Internal and External Structure ()  â€¢ Example: How do we describe the relationships between companies? â€¢ In terms of the company-to-company transactions they carry out â€¢ In terms of the business components/ services that are involved â€¢ In terms of the interactions between their employees Making Implicit Structure Explicit  â€¢ Some organizing principles impose very little structure and the structure might be implicit â€¢ co-location / pile of resources used together â€¢ arrangement by frequency of use â€¢ Coordinate systems enable absolute description of location, or we can use relative descriptions â€¢ in, on, above, below, in front of, behindâ€¦ â€¢ Statistical techniques can make explicit the structure implied by frequency distribution or correlations between properties of resources â€œBetween-Resourceâ€ Structures  â€¢ Links between printed or digital documents â€¢ Links between web pages â€¢ Links â€“ communication and information flows - between people, organizations, any other kind of interacting â€œactorsâ€ or resources â€“ social networks â€¢ We can analyze all of these with some common concepts and abstractions Between-Document Links From document to document From document component to document component From document component to document From document to document component Within-Document Links From one component to another From document component to contained document component (call out) From document component to document component, pop-up (two-way, mandatory return link) Link Network â€“ Graphical View Link Network â€“ Matrix View Link Properties  â€¢ Starting point of the link (the ANCHOR) â€¢ The end point of the link (the DESTINATION) â€¢ The reason for the link (the LINK TYPE) â€¢ The number of resource types (ARITY or DEGREE) or resource instances (CARDINALITY) linked to (- or -many) â€¢ The DIRECTIONALITY Meaning from Graph Structure  â€¢ Centrality measures â€¢ Number of incoming edges â€¢ Related nodes â€¢ â€¦ Relationships: The Architectural Perspective Paul Groth Information Organization UvA Slides from Robert J Glushko glushko@berkeleyedu @rjglushko The Architectural Perspective {and, or, vs} the Structural Perspective  â€¢ The architectural perspective is abstract and prescriptive â€¢ It defines what kinds of relationships can be created given the design of an organizing system â€¢ The structural perspective is concrete and descriptive â€¢ It says "this is what exists" and describes the actual patterns of association, arrangements, proximity, or connection between resources in a particular context The Architectural Perspective: Degree or Arity  â€¢ The architectural perspective embodies Kentâ€™s definition of â€œrelationâ€ as â€œA sequence of categories, that includes one thing from each categoryâ€ â€¢ The DEGREE or ARITY of a relationship is the number of different "entity types" or "resource categories" in the relationship â€¢ Husband is-married-to Wife is BINARY â€¢ Person is-married-to Person is UNARY The Architectural Perspective: Cardinality  â€¢ The CARDINALITY is the number of instances that can be associated with each entity type â€¢ Husband is-married-to Wife is ONE-TOONE, because husbands have only one wife and vice versa (in monogamous societies) â€¢ Father is-parent-of Child is ONE-TO-MANY â€¢ Homer is-parent-of Bart AND Lisa AND Maggie is one-to-three Modeling Relationships as Binary Ones  â€¢ Relationships can always be modeled as binary ones, but this makes some relationships implicit that were explicit â€¢ Binary relationships are relationship "triples" with a "subject", "predicate," and "object" â€¢ With binary relationships the reason for the relationship can often be interpreted in both directions (one is the inverse of the other) â€¢ With triples we can combine relationships into a graph and "reason" over the set of relationships when they have common components The Architectural Perspective: Directionality  â€¢ The DIRECTIONALITY of a relationship defines the order in which the arguments of the relationship are connected â€¢ A ONE-WAY or UNI-DIRECTIONAL relationship can be followed in only one direction â€¢ A BI-DIRECTIONAL one can be followed in both directions â€¢ All symmetric relationships are bi-directional, but not all bi-directional relationships are symmetric Relationships: The Implementation Perspective Paul Groth Information Organization UvA Slides from Robert J Glushko glushko@berkeleyedu @rjglushko Choosing an Implementation  â€¢ To communicate or process or otherwise use a relationship it needs to be represented in some implementation â€¢ The choice of implementation determines how easy it is to represent the relationship, and how easy it then is to understand and process â€¢ This means you need to consider the capabilities and biases of the intended users when choosing the implementation Contrasting Implementations (TDO )  â€¢ Natural Language â€¢ The Simpson family includes a man named Homer and a woman named Marge, the married parents of three sibling children, a boy named Bart and two girls, Lisa and Maggie â€¢ Subject-Predicate Syntax â€¢ Homer Simpson â†’ is-married-to â†’ Marge Simpson â€¢ Homer Simpson â†’ is-parent-of â†’ Bart â€¢ XML Syntax <Family name="Simpson"> <Parents children="Bart Lisa Maggie"> <Father name="Homer" spouse="Marge" /> <Mother name="Marge" spouse="Homer" /> </Parents> <Children parents="Homer Marge" > <Boy name="Bart" siblings="Lisa Maggie" /> <Girl name="Lisa" siblings="Bart Maggie" /> <Girl name="Maggie" siblings="Bart Lisa" /> </Children> </Family>

title: Six Different Kinds of Composition
topic1: kinds relationships object help referred using complexity examines associations answering
topic2: objects various aggregation reduces treating one form whole-part also referred
topic3: composition also mechanism forming whole asits parts many column ways
abstract: Composition (also referred to as aggregation ) is a mechanism for forming an object whole using other objects asits parts It reduces complexity by treating many objects as one object This column examines the ways in whichwe form these whole-part associations by answering the following questions: What are the primary kinds of composition relationships? What kinds of relationships are often confused with composition relationships? How do these various kinds of relationships help us to make correct inferences about whole-partassociations? How will these various kinds of composition help us during system development?

abstract: The Process of Organizing Information Organization UvA Paul Groth Organizing System: an intentionally arranged collection of resources and the interactions they support â€” The Discipline of Organizing  Designing Organization Systems â€¢ What is being organized? â€¢ Why its is being organized? â€¢ How much is being organized? â€¢ When is it being organized? â€¢ How or by whom is it being organized? What do we organize? What do we organize? What do we organize? â€¢ Things â€¢ Information about things â€¢ Information Affordances â€¢ Affordance: â€œa quality of an object, or an environment, which allows an individual to perform an actionâ€ (Wikipedia) â€¢ Different objects enable different organization paradigms â€¢ Clear connection in physical space â€¢ Not as clear in information space Why do we organize? Why do we organize? â€¢ Bringing things together - collection â€¢ To achieve a task â€¢ eg customer relationship management, HR, entertainment, science â€¢ To support task performance â€¢ Preservation & Archival â€¢ Broader institutional goals? â€¢ To support automation Memory Institutions How much do you have? â€¢ Personal information management â€¢ eg Filers vs Pilers (Malone, ) How much is being organized? â€¢ How much description is necessary to retrieve the right set of data? â€¢ facebook timeline vs investigative reporting â€¢ More data - more organization? â€¢ Supporting automated techniques Who is doing the organization? â€¢ Professionals (you) â€¢ Creators â€¢ Non-creator users (ie community) â€¢ Crowdsourcing â€¢ Computers â€¢ A combination When is it being organized? â€¢ Where is the investment? â€¢ On the way out? â€¢ On the way in? â€¢ Emergent organization - pay as you go Designing Organization Systems â€¢ What is being organized? â€¢ Why its is being organized? â€¢ How much is being organized? â€¢ When is it being organized? â€¢ How or by whom is it being organized? Organizing Principles Information Organization UvA  Paul Groth Organizing Principles â€œdirectives for the design or arrangement of a collection of resources that are ideally expressed in a way that does not assume any particular implementation or realizationâ€ - The Discipline of Organizing Knowledge Organization System â€¢ Systems for information organization â€¢ Traditionally, from memory institutions â€¢ Provide semantics and specify relationships between symbols and concepts to help with disambiguation, grouping, and usage Desiderata â€¢ The KOS imposes a particular view of the world on a collection and the items in it â€¢ The same entity can be characterized in different ways, depending on the KOS that is used â€¢ There must be sufficient commonality between the concept expressed in a KOS and the real-world object to which that concept refers that a knowledgeable person could apply/use the system with reasonable reliability Examples â€¢ Term Lists â€¢ eg glossaries, dictionaries, authority files (preferred terms), gazetteer, controlled vocabularies, tags â€¢ Classifications â€¢ eg taxonomy, subject headings in controlled vocabularies , folksonomys â€¢ Relationship lists â€¢ eg thesaurus, semantic networks, ontologies, mind maps, citation networks Term List Classifications Summary â€¢ Information Organization facilitates use and reuse â€¢ Information organization systems require design decisions â€¢ Knowledge organization systems have a point of view â€¢ There are many kinds of information organization The Process of Organizing Information Organization UvA Paul Groth Describing things Description is central â€¢ Organization systems enable description â€¢ Organization systems limit how things can be described Description Depends on â€¢ Goal â€¢ Context â€¢ Size â€¢ Audience â€¢ What is being organized? â€¢ Why its is being organized? â€¢ How much is being organized? â€¢ When is it being organized? â€¢ How or by whom is it being organized? Description Depends on â€¢ Goal â€¢ Context â€¢ Size â€¢ Audience â€¢ What is being organized? â€¢ Why its is being organized? â€¢ How much is being organized? â€¢ When is it being organized? â€¢ How or by whom is it being organized? Trade-offs Properties of Description â€¢ Name â€¢ Physical Properties â€¢ Cultural & Contextual properties â€¢ Structural Properties Google Structured Data Testing Tool Process of Description Good Descriptions from: The Intellectual Foundations of Information Organization Good Descriptions â€¢ User convenience â€¢ Common usage â€¢ Representation â€¢ Accuracy â€¢ Sufficiency and necessity â€¢ Significance â€¢ Standardization â€¢ Integration from: The Intellectual Foundations of Information Organization Modeling & Description â€¢ Modeling is a key task in information organization â€¢ Modeling is about making choices â€¢ Modeling provides the framework for descriptions â€¢ Modeling can have multiple notations The Problem of Naming The Vocabulary Problem Semantic Gap Semantic Gap â€œThe difference in perspective in naming and description when resources are described by automated processes rather than by peopleâ€ - The Discipline of Organizing

title: The wisdom hierarchy: representations of the DIKW hierarchy
topic1: wisdom definitions terms consensus processes revisits number variously pyramid one
topic2: information hierarchy data management articulation widely systems paper dataâ€“informationâ€“knowledgeâ€“wisdom dikw
topic3: knowledge textbooks literatures limited discussion read analysing nature models implicitly
abstract: This paper revisits the dataâ€“informationâ€“knowledgeâ€“wisdom (DIKW) hierarchy by examining the articulation of the hierarchy in a number of widely read textbooks, and analysing their statements about the nature of data, information, knowledge, and wisdom The hierarchy referred to variously as the â€˜Knowledge Hierarchyâ€™, the â€˜Information Hierarchyâ€™ and the â€˜Knowledge Pyramidâ€™ is one of the fundamental, widely recognized and â€˜taken-for-grantedâ€™ models in the information and knowledge literatures It is often quoted, or used implicitly, in definitions of data, information and knowledge in the information management, information systems and knowledge management literatures, but there has been limited direct discussion of the hierarchy After revisiting Ackoffâ€™s original articulation of the hierarchy, definitions of data, information, knowledge and wisdom as articulated in recent textbooks in information systems and knowledge management are reviewed and assessed, in pursuit of a consensus on definitions and transformation processes This process brings to the surface the extent of agreement and dissent in relation to these definitions, and provides a basis for a discussion as to whether these articulations present an adequate distinction between data, information, and knowledge Typically information is defined in terms of data, knowledge in terms of information, and wisdom in terms of knowledge, but there is less consensus in the description of the processes that transform elements lower in the hierarchy into those above them, leading to a lack of definitional clarity In addition, there is limited reference to wisdom in these texts
keywords: DIKW hierarchy, wisdom hierarchy, wisdom, knowledge management, wisdom management

abstract: Faculteit Natuurkunde, Wiskunde en Informatica Leibniz Institute System Dynamics Tom van Engers & Lera (Valeria) Krzhizhanovskaya \x0c What is System Dynamics? â€¢ System dynamics (SD) is an approach to understanding the nonlinear behaviour of complex systems over time using stocks, flows, internal feedback loops, table functions and time delays (source: https://enwikipediaorg/wiki/System_dynamics) â€¢ System Dynamics is a computer-aided approach to policy analysis and design It applies to dynamic problems arising in complex social, managerial, economic, or ecological systemsâ€“literally any dynamic systems characterized by interdependence, mutual interaction, information feedback, and circular causality (source: http://lmsystemdynamicsorg/what-is-s/) \x0c What is a system? â€¢ A system is a set of elements (also called 'componentsâ€™) with relationships between them â€¢ A system has relationships with its environment â€¢ Depending on our perspective we can choose what is in or out the system boundaries (choice!) â€¢ We can perceive/describe a system both from an internal as well as from an external perspective \x0c What is a system? â€¢ Systems have a structure defined by their components and their composistion (mereology); â€¢ Systems show behaviour, implying input, processing and output; â€¢ Systems have interconnectivity, ie different components have functional and structural relationships with eachother; â€¢ Systems have functions \x0c To understand â€˜the worldâ€™ \x0c We modelâ€¦ \x0c What is a model? â€œA model (M) for a system (S) and an experiment (E) is anything to which E can be applied in order to answer questions about Sâ€ Marvin Minski, Models, Minds, Machines,  \x0c Models++ â€¢ By definition, a model can be qualified as a system, which allows to cut out smaller pieces to generate a new model (implying a hierarchy of models) â€¢ Jack Kleijnen, â€œConcept of Meta-Models,â€ in Progress in Modelling and Simualation,  â€¢ We have to chose the level of abstraction! \x0c A road is a â€¦ (JR Hobbs,  Granularity, Morgan Kaufmann publish ) \x0c Affordances of the environment \x0c Ontological stratification \x0c Validity â€œEssentially, all models are wrong, butsome are usefulâ€ (George Box and Norman Draper) â€œThe only complete description of a systemis the system itselfâ€ (Walter Freeman)  \x0c Systems to model systems â€¢ We study (complex) systems â€¢ We make models of these systems â€¢ Ie we make systems of these systems â€¢ What are the necessary and sufficient characteristics of the latter? In other words what is the expressive power that we need given the aims of our research \x0c Remember your previous research method coursesâ€¦ â€¢ Qualitative â€“ Quantitative â€¢ Inductive â€“ Deductive â€¢ â€¦ \x0c Statistical models â€¢ study the dependency between the variables â€¢ best explanation for the variance in variables â€¢ Variables and their relationships form a acyclic directed graph! Simple regression Multiple regression Path Analysis Reduction of # of variables (PCA) Latent Variables SEM (SmartPLS) \x0c But what if the system has feedback loops? \x0c What is System Dynamics? â€¢ System dynamics (SD) is an approach to understanding the nonlinear behaviour of complex systems over time using stocks, flows, internal feedback loops, table functions and time delays (source: https://enwikipediaorg/wiki/System_dynamics) â€¢ System Dynamics is a computer-aided approach to policy analysis and design It applies to dynamic problems arising in complex social, managerial, economic, or ecological systemsâ€“literally any dynamic systems characterized by interdependence, mutual interaction, information feedback, and circular causality (source: http://lmsystemdynamicsorg/what-is-s/) \x0c System Dynamics â€¢ A model (M) for a system (S) and an experiment (E) is anything to which E can be applied in order to answer questions about S (Marvin Minski, Models, Minds, Machines, ) â€¢ In SD we experiment through simulation â€¢ A model is not necessarily a computer program â€¢ In SD we concentrate on models that can be expressed as computer programs â€¢ A model is always related to the tuple System and Experiment â€¢ Model validation relates to an experiment to be performed on a system \x0c Ways to Study a System System Experiment with the actual system Experiment with a model of the system Mathematical Model Physical Model Analytical Solution Simulation \x0c Systems, experiments, simulationâ€¦ What is a SYSTEM ? â€¢ â€œA distinguishable piece of the universe â€¢ A system is a potential source of dataâ€ (Bernard Ziegler, Theory of Modeling and Simulation, ) What is an EXPERIMENT ? â€¢ â€œAn experiment is the process of extracting data from a system by exerting it through its inputsâ€ (FranÃ§ois Cellier, Continuous System Modelling, ) What is a SIMULATION? â€¢ â€œA simulation is an experiment performed on a modelâ€ (Granino Korn and John Wait, digital continuous system simulation, ) \x0c Systems, experiments, simulationâ€¦ What is an EXPERIMENTAL FRAME? â€¢ â€œAn experimental frame is a specification of the conditions under which the system observed is experimented withâ€ (Bernard Ziegler, Theory of Modeling and Simulation, ) \x0c Mathematical simulation â€¢ A mathematical simulation is a coded description of an experiment with a reference to the model to which this experiment is applied â€¢ Note the (important) separation between model description and experiment description â€¢ Also note the potential danger of this separation; it is very easy to apply an experiment to a model for which the model is not valid System Experiment with Experiment with a the actual system model of the system Mathematical Model Physical Model Analytical Solution Simulation \x0c The Dangers of Simulation Both its strength and weakness: generality and ease of its applicationâ€¦ â€œAll too often, simulation is a love story with an unhappy ending We create a model of a system, and then fall in love with it Since love is usually blind, we immediately forget all about the experimental frame, we forget that this is not the real world, but that it represents the world only under a very limited set of experimental conditions (we become â€˜model addictsâ€™)â€ F Cellier, Continuous System Modeling,   \x0c in other words â€œDonâ€™t fall in love with your model !â€ Francois Cellier  \x0c A model has limitations â€¢ It has a domain of validity â€¢ It only represents part of the original system â€¢ Its output will not exactly match that of the original system (ie It has a limited accuracy)  \x0c Why is Modeling Important? â€œModeling means the process of organizing knowledge about a given systemâ€ Bernard Ziegler, Multifaceted Modeling and Discrete Event Simulation,  â€œ it can thus be said that modeling is the single most central activity that unites all scientific and engineering endeavors While the scientist is happy to simply observe and understand the world, ie, create a model of the world, the engineer wants to modify it to his advantage While science is all analysis, the essence of engineering is designâ€ â€œ simulation can be used not only for analysis (direct problems) but also for design (inverse problems)â€ FranÃ§ois Cellier, Continuous System Modelling,  \x0c Why model? â€¢ The physical system may not be available for experiments â€¢ Experiment may be eg too dangerous, unethical, lead to undesirable impact etc â€¢ It may be too expensive to experiment in the real world â€¢ Time scale of the system is too short/long â€¢ Control variables may be inaccessible â€¢ â€¦ â€¢ From reality to in silico experimentation similar to from reality to in vitroâ€¦ \x0c  reasons to model Explain Predict Optimize Improve Guide experiment Illuminate dynamics Suggest analogies Discover new questions Promote scientific thinking Illuminate uncertainties Crisis management in near-real time Demonstrate tradeoffs Challenge robustness of prevailing theory through perturbations Expose prevailing wisdom as incompatible with available data Support policy dialogue Train practitioners Educate general public Reveal the apparently simple (complex) to be complex (simple) â€¦â€ Epstein, Joshua M () 'Why Model?' Journal of Artificial Societies and Social Simulation () <http://jassssocsurreyacuk///html>  \x0c Examples â€¢ Car crash tests â€¢ Airplane design â€¢ Molecular docking â€¢ Banking â€¢ Computer networks Digital Twin  \x0c Things could have gone right \x0c Things can go wrong â€¢ Crash NW (), Spanair  () â€¢ Flap signal worked in simulation but not in real â€¢  + people died â€¢ Hartford Civic Center Coliseum () â€¢  acre roof collapse â€¢ Computer results misinterpreted â€¢ Love Parade disaster () â€¢ Crowd simulation used to verify safety \x0c The expectation of models and the scientists using themâ€¦ \x0c Traditional models failed in predicting the financial crisis Former ECB President Jean-Claude Trichet : â€œThe key lesson I would draw from our experience is the danger of relying on a single tool, methodology or paradigm Policymakers need to have input from various theoretical perspectives and from a range of empirical approaches We do not need to throw out our DSGE (Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium) and asset-pricing models: rather we need to develop complementary tools to improve the robustness of our overall frameworkâ€ (Trichet ) \x0c Things could have gone right â€¢ Erasmus bridge singing â€¢ Genua bridge collapsing â€¢ Power failures (eg â€¢ Trafficâ€¦(contention, roadchanges) â€¢ â€¦ â€¢ â€¦ any other examples ?? \x0c From observation to simulation Computer Experiment Implementation Algorithms Discrete approximation Model Phenomenon  \x0c Validation and Verification â€¢ Validation â€¢ Check the validity of the model â€¢ Does the model reproduce the real data? â€¢ Verification â€¢ Check the correctness of the simulation â€¢ Does the simulation program do what it is supposed to? Bugs, hidden errors? \x0c Creating SD models \x0c Causal loop diagrams (CLD) Cause + Effect \x0c Feedback loops â€¢ Simplistic view: Goals Decisions Results â€¢ Truth: Goals Decisions Results Decisions Goals Side effects â€¢ Real world: Environment Goals of others Actions of others \x0c e f  R = Reinforcing(Amplifying) B = Balancing (Stabilizing) e f  R = Reinforcing(Amplifying) B = Balancing (Stabilizing) \x0c Stock and Flow Diagram (SFD) Stock Outflow Inflow \x0c Roadpricingâ€¦ â€¢ Determine relevant factors/variables â€¢ Determine how they are related (theory!) â€¢ If used for decision making include interventions and their effects â€¢ Express the relationships in mathematical terms \x0c Inductive modeling / problem decomposition â€¢ Look for prior theories â€¢ How are these theories related â€¢ Different theories may be connected through one or more variables â€¢ (over) simplified statistics may give some clues what to look for (eg negative correlation between income and diabetes) \x0c Every initial model should be checkedâ€¦ Face validity: the extent to which your model/test is subjectively viewed as covering the concept it purports to describe/measure \x0c Summary \x0c System Dynamics â€¢ SD is an approach to understanding the nonlinear behaviour of complex systems over time using stocks, flows, internal feedback loops, table functions and time delays â€¢ SD can be applied in a wide variety of dynamic problem domains â€¢ In SD we experiment through simulation â€¢ In SD we concentrate on models that can be expressed as computer programs â€¢ A model is always related to the tuple System and Experiment â€¢ Model validation relates to an experiment to be performed on a system \x0c System Dynamics â€¢ A model (M) for a system (S) and an experiment (E) is anything to which E can be applied in order to answer questions about S (Marvin Minski, Models, Minds, Machines, ) â€¢ In SD we experiment through simulation â€¢ A model is not necessarily a computer program â€¢ In SD we concentrate on models that can be expressed as computer programs â€¢ A model is always related to the tuple System and Experiment â€¢ Model validation relates to an experiment to be performed on a system \x0c Ways to Study a System System Experiment with the actual system Experiment with a model of the system Mathematical Model Physical Model Analytical Solution Simulation \x0c Questions vanEngers@uvanl wwwLeibnizCenterorg \x0c

abstract: System Dynamics Lera (Valeria) Krzhizhanovskaya Faculty of Science computationalsciencelogo-fc-transpng \x0c Disclaimer â€¢This course is now in the â€œsecond trialâ€, perhaps not perfect yet â€¢Please help tailoring it to your interest and background â€¢I appreciate your feedback during the course, so I can try to improve it â€¢NB: Scheduling is beyond my control  \x0c  No exam! Iâ€™ve updated Canvas christmas present box celebration free picture \x0c About YOU â€¢You are great! â€¢Student count:   \x0c About me â€¢Lera (Valeria) Krzhizhanovskaya â€¢PhD in Computational Science from UvA () â€¢Researcher @ Computational Science Lab â€¢Research interests: â€“Data-driven modelling â€“Simulation of multiscale complex system â€“Machine learning, anomaly detection â€“Decision support and early warning systems â€“Policy by simulation  \x0c Some of my projects  Plasma chemical reactors \x0c Policy by Simulation projects â€¢Circular economy â€“Complex supply chains in global economy â€“Influence of social media & ICT on policy making â€“Sustainable development â€¢Smart infrastructures Predictive maintenance: Sensors \uf0e0 Monitoring \uf0e0 Modelling \uf0e0 Policy â€¢Energy transition â€¢Heath, Cities/mobility, Crime  \x0c Goals of this course â€¢To answer to the ultimate question of life, the universe, & everythingâ€¦ â€¢To develop systems thinking â€“Identify a system, boundaries, interconnections, causal relations â€¢To learn the fundamentals of modelling & simulation â€“Why model? And what? Limitations of modelling â€“Phenomenon - model - discrete - algorithm - implementation - simulation â€“Validation, verification â€¢To master the System Dynamics approach â€“Formulate models: components, structure, stocks and flows, feedback loops â€“Implement models and analyse process dynamics â€“Calibrate model parameters, study sensitivity â€“Apply to decision and policy making, suggest control strategies â€¢Learn some math behind the system dynamics â€“Formulate and solve ODEs analytically and numerically; study accuracy  \x0c L Introduction (recap) â€¢System Dynamics is â€¦ â€¢System is â€¦ â€¢Model is â€¦ â€¢Experiment is â€¦ â€¢Experimental frame is â€¦ â€¢Simulation is â€¦ â€¢Validation is â€¦ â€¢Verification is â€¦  System Experiment with the actual system Experiment with a model of the system Physical Model Mathematical Model Analytical Solution Simulation \x0c Quiz  \x0c Policy failures  â€¢Low-nicotine cigarettes increase intake of carcinogens, because smokers take more cigarettes per day â€¢Road building programs designed to reduce congestion have increased traffic, delays and pollution â€¢Fire suppression policy increased the severity of forest fires Small fires did not harm largest trees, and now lots of small dead trees fuel huge fires  \x0c Policy failures  â€¢Flood control (levees and dams) led to more severe costly floods by preventing â€œdrainageâ€ of excess water in flood plains â€¢Deregulation of the US Savings and Loan industry, designed to save the industry from financial problems, led to a wave of speculation followed by collapse â€¢HIV: New drugs save life, but now people engage in more risky behaviours, because the perceived risks is low, so the incidence of new cases grows  \x0c Policy failures   â€¢Your example? \x0c Casual loop diagrams EffectCause+ \uf04a \x0c CaUsal loop diagrams (CLD) \x0c Feedback loops  GoalsDecisionsResults â€¢Simplistic view: â€¢Truth: â€¢Real world: GoalsDecisionsResults GoalsDecisionsEnvironmentSide effectsGoals ofothersActions ofothers\x0c Positive and negative feedback  R = Reinforcing (Amplifying) B = Balancing (Stabilizing) \x0c Multi-loop systems  \x0c Stock and Flow Diagram (SFD) StockInflowOutflow\x0c  \x0c  \x0c  \x0c Chickens crossing the road  \x0c Chickens crossing the road  Chickens-to-be(in the eggs) ChickensHatchingrate+ New eggsRate of crossing theroad (death rate) ++ DeadChickenseggs per chicken ChickensTime (Month) Chickens : Current ChickensTime (Month) Chickens : Current ChickensTime (Month) Chickens : CurrentEPC= EPC= EPC= Vensim (EPC) \x0c  \x0c  \x0c  \x0c  \x0c  \x0c  \x0c  \x0c  \x0c Reading: Chapters - of the book Sterman, J (), 'Business dynamics: Systems thinking and modeling for a complex world', Boston: Irwin/McGraw-Hill  \x0c Coming next: lab sessions Finish Introduction Tutorial (Lab ) Start Assignment  \x0c

SI, SIR, SIS, SEIR, SEIS models \x0c Epidemic spreading â€“ Why? Why is the spreading process important?  \x0c â€œEpidemicâ€ Epi + demos upon people Biological: Airborne diseases (flu, SARS, â€¦) â€¢ Venereal diseases (HIV, â€¦) â€¢ Other infectious diseases including some cancers (HPV, â€¦) â€¢Parasites (bedbugs, malaria, â€¦) Digital: â€¢Computer viruses, worms â€¢Mobile phone viruses Conceptual/Intellectual: â€¢ Diffusion of innovations â€¢ Rumors â€¢ Memes â€¢ Business practices http://enwikipediaorg/wiki/Epidemic  \x0c The Great Plague SARS HIV Biological: Notable Epidemic Outbreaks  Spanish flu HN flu  \x0c Epidemic spreading â€“ Why does it matter now? High population density High mobility \uf0e0 perfect conditions for epidemic spreading Figure: L Hufnagel et al PNAS ,  ()  \x0c Separate, small population (hunter-gatherer society, wild animals) Connected, highly populated areas (cities) Large population can provide the â€œfuelâ€ Human societies have â€œcrowd diseasesâ€, which are the consequences of large, interconnected populations (Measles, tuberculosis, smallpox, influenza, common cold, â€¦)  \x0c th Century â€“ The Great Plague  years from France to Sweden Limited by the speed of human travel http://enwikipediaorg/wiki/Black_Death http://dewikipediaorg/wiki/Schwarzer_Tod  \x0c st Century â€“ SARS Source: World Health Organization  \x0c Hypponen M Scientific American Nov - () Computer Viruses, Worms, Mobile Phone Viruses Code Red Worm paralyzed many countriesâ€™ Internet http://wwwcaidaorg/publications/visualizations/  \x0c Early adopters Innovators Early majority Late majority Laggards Broadcast Contagion Diffusion of Innovation â€“ The Adoption Curve Reference unknown  \x0c Classical Epidemic Models â€“ Basic States Susceptible (healthy) Infected (sick) Removed (immune / Delays  â€œDelay always breeds dangerâ€ -Miguel de Cervantes, Don Quixote â€œNever do today what you can put off till tomorrow Delay may give clearer light as to what is best to be doneâ€ -Aaron Burr \x0c Delays are stocks  \x0c The same average delay length!  \x0c Material vs information delay â€¢Material delays â€“product delivery takes  days (pizza,  min) â€“flow of products through a delay structure â€“average delay time (residence time) â€“conserved flow â€¢Information delays â€“beliefs or perceptions adjusting to new information â€“measurement or reporting delay â€“no conserved flow  \x0c MATERIAL DELAYS  \x0c Queues and stacks â€¢FIFO = first in, first out â€“queue â€“pipeline â€“conveyer â€¢LIFO = last in, first out â€“stack â€“shelf/drawer  \x0c Pipeline delay â€¢Outflow(t+Delay)=Inflow(t)  \x0c First-order delay & perfect mixing â€¢Outflow=Material in transit/Delay  \x0c Second-order delay â€¢Stage : Outflow=Stock/Delay â€¢Stage : Outflow=Stock/Delay Stock=Ouflow-Outflow  \x0c N-th order delay  Delays \x0c Stock in transit  \x0c Erlang distribution  \x0c INFORMATION DELAYS  \x0c Adaptive expectations â€¢Inflow = Error/Delay â€¢st order exponential smoothing  \x0c rd order exponential smoothing  Vensim \x0c Material vs Information delays â€¢IF Delay(t)=Const THEN Material delay = Information delay â€¢BUT â€“Material delay: output is the exit rate from the stock â€“Information delay: output is the stock O  DO - DI DO)(IdtdO \uf03d \uf02d \uf03d\x0c Canvas Quiz L Delays  \x0c computationalsciencelogo-fc-transpng Aging chains \x0c  â€¢Transition rate = Ci/YPCi â€¢YPCi = years per cohort i â€¢Usually st order delay â€¢Examples: â€“startup \uf0e0 SME \uf0e0 corporation â€“hiring and promotion â€“disease development â€“population demographic pyramid populationpyramidnet \x0c Reading â€¢Chapters ,  (Sterman , Systems Thinkingâ€¦)  \x0c Coming next â€¢Assignment   \x0c

worst point wrt the other N points â€¢Now you can search for a better point on the line joining the original and the new point â€¢Depending on the result, a new simplex is generated using the new point and the N original points http://enwikipediaorg/wiki/Nelder-Mead_method  \x0c When S defines a complex landscape Use Monte-Carlo methods (simulated annealing, genetic algorithms, Latin hypercube, etc) Tatra gebergte, wwwtravlangcom  \x0c Simulated annealing () â€¢Idea related to the annealing (heat treatment) of metal â€¢Basic step at temperature T: â€“Choose an initial configuration (parameters) yielding a quality Q (here a lower Q is better) â€“Apply a random parameter modification Compute Q â€“If Q < Q , accept the new parameters â€¢A real improvement â€“Otherwise: Choose a random value r:  < r <  â€“If r < exp((Q â€“ Q )/T) accept after all â€¢Allows escape from a local minimum  \x0c Simulated annealing () â€¢The basic step performs a â€œconstrained random walkâ€, dependent on T â€“A high value of T will not strongly constrain the random walk â€¢Gradually lower the temperature â€“Either continuously, or after a number of basic steps â€¢Method is based op â€œMarkov chainsâ€ â€¢Also suitable for discrete problems like the travelling salesman problem (TSP)  \x0c An example National flu measurement - https://wwwdegrotegriepmetingnl               ILI A B New cases per   per week  \x0c                  ILI Model Fit a SEIR model to flu data New cases per   per week Days  \x0c Fit a SEIR model to flu data Model: SEIR with E and I phase subdivided into three equal subphases Parameters: â€¢Population   people (fixed) â€¢First case: day  â€¢Infectiousness:  cases/(day*person) â€¢Incubation time:  days â€¢Duration:  days â€¢Preexisting immunity: %  \x0c Procedure â€¢Searched -dimensional parameter space on a relatively course grid â€¢Search time: a few minutes â€¢Value of the result: â€“None, the model ignores too many relevant aspects of the problem â€“Correlations allow connected parameters to be changed significantly together without much change in the quality of the fit  \x0c For influenza A -                Infl A Fit New cases per   per week Days  \x0c Fitting SEIR model for Infl A Model: SEIR with E and I phase subdivided into three Parameters (obtained using simulated annealing) â€¢Population   people (fixed) â€¢First case: day  â€¢Infectiousness:  cases/(day*person) (very high) â€¢Incubation time: <  day (too short) â€¢Duration:  days (too long) â€¢Preexisting immunity: % (very high ??) RESULT: â€¢Large range of similarly good fits as parameters correlate â€¢Which correlations would you expect?  \x0c Procedure â€¢Search in  dimensional parameter space using simulated annealing â€¢Speed: faster than preceding â€œexhaustive searchâ€ â€¢Relevance of the result: â€“None, too many effects not taken into account â€“Correlated parameters lead to large uncertainties in fit  \x0c â€¢Build a model from observations â€¢Process & analyze the measurements â€¢Check for correlations â€¢Adjust model parameters â€“Least squares, weights â€“Other optimization methods What to learn  \x0c Canvas Quiz L  \x0c Reading â€¢Chapters ,  (Sterman , Systems Thinkingâ€¦) â€¢Advanced (only for those interested in math): Heath , Scientific Computing An Introductory Survey  \x0c Coming next â€¢Results of Assignment  (end of the week) â€¢Work on Assignment   \x0c

â€œconstrained random walkâ€, dependent on T â€“A high value of T will not strongly constrain the random walk â€¢Gradually lower the temperature â€“Either continuously, or after a number of basic steps â€¢Method is based on â€œMarkov chainsâ€ â€¢Also suitable for discrete problems like the travelling salesman problem (TSP)  \x0c An example National flu measurement - https://wwwdegrotegriepmetingnl               ILI A B New cases per   per week  \x0c                  ILI Model Fit a SEIR model to flu data New cases per   per week Days  \x0c Fit a SEIR model to flu data Model: SEIR with E and I phase subdivided into three equal subphases Parameters: â€¢Population   people (fixed) â€¢First case: day  â€¢Infectiousness:  cases/(day*person) â€¢Incubation time:  days â€¢Duration:  days â€¢Preexisting immunity: %  \x0c Procedure â€¢Searched -dimensional parameter space on a relatively course grid â€¢Search time: a few minutes â€¢Value of the result: â€“Little, since the model ignores many relevant aspects of the problem â€“Correlations allow connected parameters to be changed significantly together without much change in the quality of the fit  \x0c For influenza A -                Infl A Fit New cases per   per week Days  \x0c Fitting SEIR model for Infl A Model: SEIR with E and I phase subdivided into  phases Parameters (obtained using simulated annealing) â€¢Population   people (fixed) â€¢First case: day  â€¢Infectiousness:  cases/(day*person) (very high) â€¢Incubation time: <  day (too short) â€¢Duration:  days (too long) â€¢Preexisting immunity: % (very high ??) RESULT: â€¢Large range of similarly good fits as parameters correlate â€¢Which correlations would you expect?  \x0c â€¢Build a model from observations â€¢Process & analyze the measurements â€¢Check for correlations â€¢Adjust model parameters â€“Least squares, weights â€“Other optimization methods What to learn  \x0c Canvas Quiz L  \x0c Reading â€¢Chapters  (Sterman , Systems Thinkingâ€¦) â€¢Advanced reading (if you are interested in numerical methods): Heath  Scientific Computing An Introductory Survey  \x0c Assignment  data fit â€¢Python scripts extend the functionality of Vensim free version (data fit, optimization and sensitivity) â€¢In Modules \uf0e0 Python scripts: Install python (see pythonInstallationpdf) Data fitting folder with scripts Model calibration and optimisation exercises page (with answers)  \x0c Coming next â€¢Finalise Assignment  â€¢Take into account feedback on Assignment  â€¢Start thinking about your Team Project (more in next lecture) â€“Teams of  students â€“Topic of your own interest â€“Demonstrate everything youâ€™ve learnt  \x0c

And what? Limitations of modelling â€“Phenomenon - model - discrete - algorithm - implementation - simulation â€“Validation, verification â€¢To master the System Dynamics â€“Formulate models: components, structure, stocks and flows, feedback loops â€“Implement models and analyse process dynamics â€“Calibrate model parameters, study sensitivity â€“Apply to decision and policy making, suggest control strategies â€¢Learn some math behind the system dynamics â€“Formulate and solve ODEs analytically and numerically; study accuracy  \x0c Project steps by Sterman   Problem articulation (framework, variables, time, data, behaviour reference modes)  Formulation of dynamical hypothesis (theory, casual structure, relations, CLD)  Formulation of a simulation model (SFD, parameter estimations, verification)  Testing (validation, robustness, sensitivity, UQ)  Policy design and evaluation (scenarios, decision rules, strategies, what-if analysis, sensitivity, policy interactions)  Sterman  Chapter  \x0c computationalsciencelogo-fc-transpng Controlling complex dynamical systems (related to policy making and decision support) & Control Theory \x0c Policy \uf0e8 Decision \uf0e8 How to control? â€¢Remember about policy failures! (Lecture ) â€¢Can we control this? \uf0e0 â€¢Yes â†“  Related image Related image \x0c Unlessâ€¦  How can we control this? Image result for overflow bathtub Related image \x0c Control types â€¢Strategic control â€“Adding controlling feedback loops â€¢Automatic control â€“Adjusting control parameters to automatically tune the system states  \x0c Strategic control Policy \uf0e8 \uf0e8 Decision \uf0e8 Expected behaviour (goals) \uf0e8 Possible causes of deviation \uf0e8 Add controlling feedback loops or other elements of SFD (change structure) \uf0e8 Prevent or correct deviations  \x0c Automatic control â€¢Find control parameter values for efficient correction of system behaviour \uf0e8 We need to study the sensitivity to new parameters in the controlling feedback loops \uf0e8 then we optimise these control parameters  \x0c Controlling the control loops â€¢IF controlling structure is complex (eg more than one feedback loop) THEN conditional switches may be needed OR a new loop controlling the control loops  \x0c Theory of controllability â€¢Is it possible to keep it under control? â€¢In complex systems, we often donâ€™t know â€“Complex interactions â€“We canâ€™t test all combinations of model parameters â€“Random events â€“Unknown factors â€¢What to do? â€“Mathematical theory of controllability (analysis of state-transition matrix, ranks) â€¢We have to prepare for the unexpected!  \x0c What can we control easily? â€¢Flow rates â€¢Delays  + Fig - \x0c Fig - Supply chain control  \x0c TIPS FOR â€œCONTROLLABLEâ€ SFD  \x0c Real stock outflows require control â€¢Preventing negative stocks: â€¢Stock= INTEGRAL(Inflow - Outflow, Stock(t)) â€¢Outflow = MIN(Desired Outflow, Max_Outflow) â€¢Max_Outflow = Stock/Min_residence_time  \x0c Avoid IF THEN ELSE â€¢Conditional switch adds discontinuity â€¢Sometimes not realistic (especially on aggregate system level)  \x0c Disaggregate net flows â€¢Net Hiring = (Desired Labor - Labor)/Delay â€¢But hiring delay >> firing delay â€¢Hiring Rate = MAX(, Indicated Net Hiring) â€¢Layoff Rate = MIN(Indicated Layoff Rate, Maximum Layoff Rate) â€¢Indicated Layoff Rate = MAX(, -Indicated Hiring Rate)  \x0c Reading â€¢Chapters , control loop examples Ch - (Sterman , Systems Thinkingâ€¦)  \x0c

filename: John D Sterman - Business Dynamics Systems Thinking and Modeling for a Complex World-McGraw-Hill Higher Education (2000).pdf
title: John D Sterman - Business Dynamics Systems Thinking and Modeling for a Complex World-McGraw-Hill Higher Education (2000).pdf
topic1: system dynamics developed complexity originally massachusetts forrester method managers design
topic2: book dynamics approach unique public leverage sustainable success business systems
topic3: system dynamics study institute technology lay devised help policymakers high
abstract: System dynamics is an approach to the study of complexity. Originally developed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology by lay Forrester, system dynamics is a unique method devised to help managers and public policymakers design and implement high leverage policies for sustainable success. In a comprehensive new treatment, John Sterman, a Jeading authority on system dynamics, explains what system dynamics is and how it can be successfully applied to solve business and organizational problems. Business Dynamics includes principles for modelling complex dynamic systems, simulation models, experiential exercises, and case studies of successful applications. The CD-ROM included with the book and the dedicated book website contain the models developed in the text, along with all the software needed to run, test, and extend them, thereby helping to increase student participation in the learning process.
category_topics: product, service, customer, business, market, opportunity, uf, idea, company, change

Psychologic foundations â€¢ Events in the society or social environment can cause radicalisation of opinions [] â€¢ These opinions justify opponent activities â€¢ This process also reversible â€¢ Deradicalization & disengagement [] â€¢ Pull and Push factors â€¢ Individual development â€¢ Social environment â€¢ Violence, disillusion Process of radicalisation [] [] McCauley, C, & Moskalenko, S Disengagement from Ideologically-Based and Violent Organizations; A Systematic Review of the Literature Journal for Deradicalization, (), - \x0c The Institute Amsterdam Economical foundation: Rational Choice Theory â€¢ Routine activity theory: The situation shapes the individual [] â€¢ This situation is influenced by opportunities and threats in their social networks and environment â€¢ Individuals decide rationally to maximize the utility of their human and social capital â€¢ (De)Radicalisation influences the rationality of the decisions [] Clarke, R V, & Felson, M () Routine activity and stateâ€, â€intention stateâ€ â€œaction stateâ€ and decide rationally â€¢ Possible actions are â€œmoveâ€, â€change networksâ€, â€workâ€, â€perform crimeâ€, â€initiate a hierarchyâ€, to cope with the adversity â€¢ Environment consists of law enforcement threats and social and opponent opportunities â€¢ Law enforcement can target specific opponents: â€¢ Those with highest rewards â€¢ Focus on infiltration \x0c The Institute Amsterdam â€¢ Verification: â€¢ Documentation â€¢ Code Walkthrough â€¢ Programmatic testing â€¢ Life cycle validation: â€¢ Input validation â€¢ Micro-face â€¢ Macro-face â€¢ Output validation  | An agent-based model for emergent opponent behaviour  August  \x0c The Institute Amsterdam Model analysis: Hypothesis Influence of law enforcement activity â€¢ Hypothesis : The form of cooperation by opponents will shift from a hierarchical form to a network as law enforcement agencies intensify their actions â€¢ Hypothesis : Hierarchical organisations will be smaller and less dense in scenarios with higher law enforcement intensity â€¢ Hypothesis : Cooperation by individuals in networks will be less dense as law enforcement agencies focus on infiltration of networks Influence of social and opponent opportunity â€¢ Hypothesis : The amount of opponents will decline by a growth of social opportunity â€¢ Hypothesis : Individuals will deradicalize as the amount of opponent opportunity declines \x0c The Institute Amsterdam Experiment : vary law enforcement \x0c The Institute Amsterdam Experiment : vary law enforcement When ampl - book/chapter - downloads/ â€¢ Debugging: start simple and increase complexity â€¢ Some syntax: â€“  - dim binary variables: var x {N, M} binary; â€“ constraint for all i,j , iâ‰ j : subject to example_constraint { i in N, j in M: i <>j}: x[ i,j ] <= ; Mind the closing sign!  NEOS server â€¢ Free service for solving optimization problems at wwwneos - serverorg/neos/ â€¢ Provides access to >  state - of - the - art solvers â€¢ Optimization routine: Transform o ptimization problem to suitable input Suitable for a problem type (ILO, LO, â€¦) and the requested solver Upload Solve Output (solution) Using AMPL & CPLEX in our case  AIMMS Screenshot I Definition of the objective Complete IDE to help setup the model  AIMMS Screenshot II Afbeeldingsresultaat voor aimms Possibility to develop (online) applications for end -
