Fulkerson) â€¢ Sometimes general (branch & bound, genetic algorithms, dynamic optimization) â€¢ Sometimes optimum guaranteed - sometimes best - effort ( heuristic ) â€¢ Complexity â‰ˆ runtime of algorithm  Rest of algorithms outline For the following  classical problems: â€“ Shortest path â€“ Maximum flow â€“ Traveling salesman = shortest tour we will present (resp): â€¢ an (I)LO formulation â€¢ an algorithm  Shortest path problem â€¢ Given a network with distances given by c ij â€™s (â‰¥), find a shortest path from source s to destination d â€¢ Example: Find shortest path from s = A ïƒ  d = F Afbeeldingsresultaat voor navigation â€œDistance from D ïƒ  F is c DF = â€ A C F B D E           LO of shortest path â€¢ LO = special case transshipment problem with demand  at destination â€¢ Decision variables: x ij =  if i â†’ j used,  else â€¢ Objective: min âˆ‘ i,j c ij x ij ( c ij = âˆ if no i ïƒ  j) â€¢ Constraints: ï‚§ âˆ‘ j x s j - âˆ‘ j x j s =  for s = source ï‚§ âˆ‘ i x i d - âˆ‘ j x d j =  for d = destination ï‚§ âˆ‘ j x ij = âˆ‘ j x ji for all other nodes i ï‚§ x ij â‰¥ , âˆ€ i,j n  variables (n nodes) n constraints Special LO: no need to force x ij ïƒ {,} (i f solution non - integer: any >  connection is optimal)  Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm â€¢ Algorithm by Edsger Dijkstra in  â€¢ Finds the shortest paths from source to all nodes â€¢ Important: non - negative connections â€¢ Starting from the source, we will iteratively visit all nodes (once), this leads to: â€“ Visited nodes which we put in set W â€“ Unvisited nodes Afbeeldingsresultaat voor dijkstra Edsger Dijkstra ( â€“ ) Once visited, Dijkstra proved that we have found a shortest path from source to this visited node  Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm â€¢ We will construct for growing W for all x: d W (x) = shortest path length from source to x using only intermediate nodes from set W â€¢ Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm: ï‚§ Start: W = empty, d W (â€œsourceâ€) = , d W (â€œrestâ€) = âˆ ï‚§ While â€œ W contains not all nodesâ€: ï‚§ Find x not in W with smallest d W (x), say xâ€™ ï‚§ Visit xâ€™ (add to W ) and thereby making it current ï‚§ Update d W (x) = min{ d W \ xâ€™ ( xâ€™ ) + c xâ€™ ,x ; d W \ xâ€™ (x)}, for all x not in W â€¢ When updating: save â€œprevious nodeâ€ â€¢ Runtime in case of n nodes = n  , very fast! Screen Shot -- at  png Our aim: d â€œall nodesâ€ (â€œ dest â€) W \ xâ€™ = W without xâ€™  Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm Example: Find shortest path from A ïƒ  F Step \ x A B C D E F Current W Start  âˆ âˆ âˆ âˆ âˆ A {} Step   (A)  (A) âˆ âˆ âˆ C {A} Step   (A)  (C)  (C) âˆ B {A, C} Step   (C)  (C) âˆ E {A, C, B} Step   (E)  (E) D {A, C, B, E} Step   (E) F {A, C, B, E, D} Step  {A, C, B, E, D, F} A C F B D E          A C F B D E                Distances d W (x) throughout algorithm: â€œThe shortest path from A to D is A ïƒ  C ïƒ  E ïƒ  D and has length â€  Maximum flow problem Motivating example Road network analysis: What is the maximum traffic flow between two locations? Any bottlenecks? Afbeeldingsresultaat voor file nederland Gerelateerde afbeelding  Maximum flow problem â€¢ Given a directed network with: â€“ Source node s â€“ Destination node d â€“ Edge capacity c ij between all nodes i and j â€¢ Goal: find the maximum feasible flow from source to destination that respects: â€“ The capacity constraints â€“ Flow conservation principle: what comes into a node, should also come out (except at nodes s & d )  Maximum flow example Example: Find the maximum flow from s =A ïƒ  d =F given the flow capacities over the edges A C F B D E          Note: eg, A ïƒ  D can be thought of as capacity c AD =  c DF =  means that the maximum flow from D ïƒ  F is   Maximum flow LO (n nodes): â€¢ Decision variables: x ij = flow from i ïƒ  j , âˆ€ i , j â€¢ Objective: max âˆ‘ j x s j ( s = source) â€¢ Constraints: ï‚§ Capacity constraints: x ij â‰¤ c ij , âˆ€ i , j ï‚§ Flow conservation ( d = destination): âˆ‘ i x ij = âˆ‘ i x ji , âˆ€ j: j â‰  s and j â‰  d ï‚§ Non - negative flow: x ij â‰¥ , âˆ€ i , j n  variables n â€“  constraints n  constraints n  constraints  Maximum flow algorithm An augmenting path from s to d is only composed of: â€¢ Forward edges i ïƒ  j whose capacities are not reached â€¢ Reversed edges j ïƒ  i with positive flow Key idea: flow from source to destination can be increased along the augmenting path Idea Ford â€“ Fulkerson algorithm: when no augmenting path can be found anymore, a maximum flow is reached (by increasing flow on every forward edge and decreasing the flow on the reversed edges as much as possible)  Ford â€“ Fulkerson algorithm Ford â€“ Fulkerson algorithm: Repeat until â€œno more augmenting pathâ€  Find augmenting path from s to d  Increase flow along augmenting path and update edge capacities available (residual graph) Optimality test: â€“ Any s - d flow is no greater than any cut value â€“ Maximum flow = minimum cut value The total capacity of edges that when cut , disconnects s from d  Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Find maximum flow from A ïƒ  F B C F B D E           Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Find maximum flow from A ïƒ  F  Find augmenting path from A to F B C F B D E           Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Find maximum flow from A ïƒ  F  Increase flow along augmenting path and update edge capacities B C F B D E /  /      / Max flow along the augmenting path is determined by this capacity â€œA flow of  flows from D to F which has a capacity of â€  Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Find maximum flow from A ïƒ  F  Find augmenting path from A to F B C F B D E /  /      / Max flow along the augmenting path is determined by this capacity, ie, flow increase of   Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Find maximum flow from A ïƒ  F  Increase flow along augmenting path and update edge capacities B C F B D E / / /   /   /  Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Find maximum flow from A ïƒ  F  Find augmenting path from A to F B C F B D E / / /   /   /  Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Find maximum flow from A ïƒ  F  Increase flow along augmenting path and update edge capacities B C F B D E / / / /  / /  / Note: the capacity from C ïƒ  D is reached now, but we now may push a flow of max  back from D ïƒ  C if that would give us an augmenting path  Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Find maximum flow from A ïƒ  F  Find augmenting path from A to F B C F B D E / / / /  / /  /  Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Find maximum flow from A ïƒ  F  Increase flow along augmenting path and update edge capacities B C F B D E / / / / / / /  /  Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Find maximum flow from A ïƒ  F  Find augmenting path from A to F B C F B D E / / / / / / /  / Not possible anymore to find an augmenting path! Ford - Fulkerson Algorithm: a max flow has been found of value  This cut has a capacity of ++ =  Since the max flow value is  this verifies the optimality of the max flow  Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Illustration augmenting flow with reversed edge â€¢ Goal is to find the maximum flow from A ïƒ  D â€¢ Suppose after a first iteration we have the following C B / A  / D /   Find augmenting path Reversed edge C ïƒ  B where we can push a flow of  backwards  Ford â€“ Fulkerson example Illustration augmenting flow with reversed edge â€¢ Goal is to find the maximum flow from A ïƒ  D â€¢ Suppose after a first iteration we have the following C B / A / / D / /  Increase flow along augmenting path Pushing back the flow of  along this edge leads to / In the next iteration: no augmenting path anymore Ford - Fulkerson Algorithm: a max flow has been found of value   Traveling salesmen problem (TSP) Afbeeldingsresultaat voor order picking Synopsis figure What is the shortest route that visits each city and returns to the origin city? Afbeeldingsresultaat voor delivery company Applications: Afbeeldingsresultaat voor microchips  TSP â€¢ Given a network of n nodes (cities) with distances given by c ij between all nodes i , j â€¢ Goal: find the shortest tour visiting all nodes and returning to start node Example Eg, tour A ïƒ  B ïƒ  D ïƒ  F ïƒ  E ïƒ  C ïƒ  A has a length of   A C F B D E           TSP ILO model ILO model: â€¢ Decision variables: x ij = , i, j = , â€¦, n â€¢ Objective : min âˆ‘ i,j c ij x ij â€¢ Constraints : ï‚§ âˆ‘ i x ij = âˆ‘ i x ji = , âˆ€ j ï‚§ To prevent subtours : add: âˆ‘ i,j âˆˆ S x ij < |S|, for all node subsets S:  â‰¤ |S| â‰¤ n -  , use i ïƒ  j , else Satisfies the first set of constraints, but no tour number of different S =  n , thus â‰ˆ n constraints! When traveling to city j, we should also leave this city  |S| = size S  TSP Algorithm Enumeration â€œnaÃ¯veâ€ algorithm: Iterate over all possible tours:  Calculate total distance current tour  If better than current best ïƒ  new best However: â€¢ (n - )! = (n - )*(n - )* â€¦ ** possible tours â€¢ So runtime algorithm is approx n!  TSP Algorithm Some values for polynomial and non - polynomial functions: Really non - practical for reasonable sized instancesâ€¦ Canâ€™t we do better ? (also not by a quantum computer: âˆš of the numbers)  Outline Practical aspects of real - life optimization: â€¢ Solvers â€¢ Modeling tools: Algebraic modeling languages and environments â€¢ Algorithms â€¢ Complexity theory â€¢ Heuristics  Complexity theory Based on running time of solving algorithm, roughly two problem classes: NP - complete P  Complexity theory Roughly, two classes of problems: â€¢ P : â€“ Algorithms known that find optimal solutions even for large instances â€“ Eg, transportation, shortest path, product mix â€¢ NP - complete : â€“ No fast algorithms known â€¦ â€“ Heuristics for large instances â€“ Eg, knapsack, machine scheduling, set covering, TSP  How to win a million? Do one of the following: a Find a fast* algorithm for solving a NP - complete problem b Proof that there does not exist a fast* algorithm for solving a NP - complete problem and call meâ€¦ ïŠ (Hint: most researchers believe that b is true) The Clay Mathematics Institute awards a US$ million prize for an answer * Polynomial time algorithm Afbeeldingsresultaat voor money funny  Outline Practical aspects of real - life optimization: â€¢ Solvers â€¢ Modeling tools: Algebraic modeling languages and environments â€¢ Algorithms â€¢ Complexity theory â€¢ Heuristics  Heuristics for TSP â€¢ No fast algorithm known for solving TSP â€¢ Heuristics aim not for optimum but for good solutions in reasonable time â€¢ Example:  - opt heuristic for TSP to be discussed next â€¢ Good heuristics ( - opt,) have near - optimal performance  TSP heuristic  - opt â€¢  - opt heuristic for TSP : â€“ Find an initial tour (eg, randomly move to a non - visited node) â€“ Remove  by  all couples of tour edges â€“ Reconnect for valid tour using other  edges â€“ If improvement: move to this new tour â€“ Repeat until no improvements Tour Distance Swap  Local minimum where the â€œswappingâ€ stops Global minimum Swap  Swap  â€œSwapâ€ (see next slide) Initial tour  TSP heuristic  - opt Example  - opt swap leading to better tour A C F B D E

abstract: Statistics, Simulation & Optimization Lecture  Joost Berkhout, VU  Program â€¢ Lecture : Linear optimization â€¢ Lecture : Advanced modeling â€¢ Lecture : Solvers, heuristics, complexity â€¢ Lecture : Simulation â€¢ Lecture : Simulation optimization â€¢ Lecture : Dynamic optimization â€¢ Lecture : W rap - up  Recap Real - life problem Model r() Output r( Ï€ ) Input â€œRepresented byâ€ - Fixed parameters - Decision Ï€ âˆˆ S Problem form: max r(Ï€) st Ï€ âˆˆ S â€¢ S often very large (eg, TSP: |S| = (n - )!) â€¢ Algorithms to find solution can be â€“ â€œpolynomialâ€ (eg, LO, Dijkstra ) â€“ â€œnon - polynomialâ€ (eg, TSP, ILO) â€¢ But r( Ï€ ) can always be computed easily Afbeeldingsresultaat voor money funny Reminder:  million dollar opportunity  Today Real - life problem Input â€œRepresented byâ€ - Random parameters X - Decision Ï€ âˆˆ S Problem form: max E[ r( X, Ï€ ) ] st Ï€ âˆˆ S â€¢ Next two lectures: r( X, Ï€) can only be evaluated by simulation Simulation - based optimization â€¢ Today: no decisions (Ï€ âˆˆ S fixed), only randomness: ïƒ˜ Monte Carlo simulation of known function r( X) and known dimension of X (â€œspreadsheet simulationâ€) ïƒ˜ Discrete - event simulation of more complex r( X ) Model r() Output r( X, Ï€ )  Goals today â€¢ Expectation and variance of random variables ( rvâ€™s ) in simulation context â€¢ Simulation of a random variable â€¢ Discrete - event simulation â€¢ Statistical analysis of simulation results  Simulation of model r() Simulation setting Afbeeldingsresultaat voor data Data analysis parameters Probability distribution fit Generating parameter data x  , x  , â€¦, x n â€œin line with real - life dataâ€ Process in model r() Statistical analysis  Motivating example â€¢ Project planning with random durations â€¢ Number given is expected duration â€¢ What is project finish time? â€¢ Depends on realizations (â€œxâ€) of durations: finish time = r( x A , x B , , x G ) â€¢ Objective: expected project finish time  Reminder: Random variables â€¢ Randomness is covered in a rv X â€¢ Two types of rvâ€™s X: â€“ Discrete: eg, X = sum of rolling two dices â€“ Continuous: eg, X = number drawn from [a, b] ( < a < b) Probability distribution for the sum of two six-sided dice Afbeeldingsresultaat voor throwing a dice probabilities Afbeeldingsresultaat voor uniform distribution   pdf cdf Afbeeldingsresultaat voor uniform distribution   pdf cdf Probability of throwing  is / No direct probability notion Probability that number â‰¤ ( a+b )/ is / (a + b)/ / (cumulative distribution function ( cdf )) (probability density function (pdf)) (= P(X â‰¤ x)) (P(x) = probability mass function ( pmf ))  Reminder: Expectation â€¢ Random variable X, some function r(X) â€¢ The expectation of r(X), E[r(X)], is defined as follows: â€“ X discrete: â€“ X has density f: â€¢ In general: E[r(X)] â‰  r(E[X]) â€¢ X often multi - dim: complicated calculation â€¢ Solution: simulation  Reminder: Variance â€¢ The variance of a rv X is defined as Ïƒ  ( X) = E[(X â€“ EX)  ] (note: X can be replaced by rv r(X)) â€¢ Intuition: â€œ Ïƒ  ( X) measures the spread of samples of X around EXâ€ â€¢ Ïƒ ( X) is the standard deviation of X  Simulation â€¢ How to simulate from r(X ) ? â€¢ Generate independent samples x  , x  , â€¦, x n of a random variable X â€¢ This gives samples r(x  ), r(x  ), â€¦, r( x n ) of r(X ) â€¢ Note : r(X ) is itself a rv thus focus on X â€¢ Claim: the sample average (x  + x  + â€¦ + x n ) / n converges to EX for increasing n â€¢ Why does it converge ?  Law of large numbers (LLN) â€¢ Consider rv X i of the i - th random sample â€¢ Assume X i iid with X i = X (EX, Ïƒ  ( X)) â€¢ Then: ï‚§ E[(X  +â€¦+ X n ) / n] = ( Î£ i E X i ) / n = EX ï‚§ Ïƒ  [(X  +â€¦+ X n ) / n] = ( Î£ i Ïƒ  ( X i ) ) / n  = Ïƒ  ( X) / n (see next slide for the used properties) â€¢ â€œ Thus â€ : (X  +â€¦+ X n ) / n â†’ EX for n â†’ âˆ d LLN: Sample average of the simulation converges to expected performance (Random) sample average  Reminder: Properties â€¢ E[X + Y] = EX + EY â€¢ E[ aX ] = aEX â€¢ Ïƒ  (X + Y) = Ïƒ  (X) + Ïƒ  (Y) if X and Y independent â€¢ Ïƒ  ( aX ) = a  Ïƒ  (X), Ïƒ ( aX ) = a Ïƒ (X) â€¢ Ïƒ (X) has the same unit as X why mathematicians like the variance why practicioners like the standard deviation  Example â€¢ Project planning of A, B and C: â€¢ Rvâ€™s of durations: X A , X B and X C â€¢ X A , X B , X C iid lognormal(, ) distributed â€¢ Finish time r(X A ,X B ,X C ) = max(X A , X B ) + X C â€¢ Goal: expected finish time E[ r(X A ,X B ,X C ) ] A B C Activity duration lognormal(,  ) pdf  Example (continued) What is E[max(X A ,X B ) + X C ]? A B C  Example (continued) â€¢ Simulation outcomes + running averages Average finishing time project C up until  realizations  Distribution sampling â€¢ Why LOGNORM INV ? â€¢ Inverse transformation method (ITM) â€¢  steps (F is the distribution function of X): ) Sample u from a uniform [,] dist with rv U ) x = F -  (u) is a sample from X x - values Cdf F(x) = P(X â‰¤ x) â€œSample uniformly from this interval [ ,] and return cdf corresponding x - valueâ€ u F -  (u ) Remark: Sometimes no exact expression known for F -  (eg, normal distribution , but approximation methods exist )  Working ITM â€¢ ITM works because for all x: P(F -  (U) ï‚£ x) = P(U ï‚£ F( x)) = F(x) = P(X ï‚£ x), thus F -  (U) = X Intuition: d Exponential pdf Normal pdf Normal cdf Exponential cdf Intuition ITM: â€œThe steeper F(x) increases on an interval for x, the more likely samples F -  (U ) will map to this interval This is nicely in line with the corresponding pdfâ€  Sampling in practice â€¢ Almost any programming language has a random number generator (RNG) that can sample u from a uniform [,] distribution â€¢ Uniform [a, b] sample (ITM ): a + (b â€“ a)* u â€¢ Many languages have libraries for F -  â€¢ Some languages have functions to directly sample from common distributions (eg, normal and exponential distributions ) â€¢ In general : RNGs are not purely random and rely often on seeds ïƒ  useful for replication purposes  â€¢ Excel: â€“ RAND() gives uniform[,] â€“ NORMINV() gives inverse of normal distribution â€“ GAMMAINV () gives inverse of gamma distribution â€“ BINOMINV() gives inverse of binomial distribution â€“ Tools â†’ Data Analysis gives also random numbers â€¢ R â€“ runif (), rnorm (), etc generates samples â€“ qnorm ( runif (n)) does same thing as rnorm (n) â€“ setseed () sets seed of random generator Sampling in practice  Really random? Random bitmap based on atmospheric noise Randomorg Bitmap Random bitmap based on PHP's rand() function in Windows PHP rand() on Windows Bitmap Source: https://boallencom/random - numbershtml Really random: based on atmospheric noise  ITM example : sampling from the exponential distribution â€¢ Let X ~ Exp ( Î» ) with cdf F(x ): F(x) =  - e - Î» x â€¢ F(x) = u â‡”F -  (u) = x = - log( - u) / Î» â€¢ U ~ uniform [,] ïƒ U =  - U â€¢ Thus inverse transformation method: ) Randomly sample u from [,] ) Calculate - log(u) / Î» In Excel: - ln(rand()) / â€œlambdaâ€ d  ITM example : Discrete distribution sampling â€¢ Example : P(X = ) = / & P(X = ) = / â€¢ F -  (u) = min { x | F(x) â‰¥ u } â€¢ Practice : I Partition [,] into non - overlapping subintervals corresponding to all possible discrete outcomes II Draw from [,], see in which subinterval it falls and return corresponding discrete outcome - â‰¤ u â‰¤ /: sample =  / < u â‰¤ : sample =  F(x) (= P(X â‰¤ x)) x  Central Limit Theorem â€¢ How quickly does average converge? â€¢ Take Y n = (X  +â€¦+ X n ) / n (X i iid with X i =X) â€¢ LLN: E Y n = EX, Ïƒ  ( Y n ) = Ïƒ  ( X) / n ( <âˆ) â€¢ To get a limit: study Z n = ïƒ– n ( Y n â€“ EX) â€¢ Then: E Z n = , Ïƒ  ( Z n ) = Ïƒ  ( X) â€¢ Central Limit Theorem (CLT) : Z n â†’ N(, Ïƒ  ( X)) d Read as: Z n converges to the distribution as n tends to infinity N(Î¼, Ïƒ  ) is normal distribution with expectation Î¼ and variance Ïƒ  ( Ïƒ is standard deviation) d  Confidence interval (CI) â€¢ The CLT is about a limit â€¢ For finite n the normal distribution is used as an approximation â€¢ Rv Y n is approximately distributed as N( EX , Ïƒ  ( X)/n) Afbeeldingsresultaat voor normal distribution EX % within  standard deviations ( Ïƒ ( X)/âˆšn) from EX  Experiment Screen Shot -- at  png Screen Shot -- at  png Screen Shot -- at  png Screen Shot -- at  png Histogram of: â€¢  samples Y  â€¢  samples Y  â€¢  samples Y  â€¢  samples Y  (For a live experiment click here )   â‰ˆP( EX -  Ïƒ ( X)/ âˆš n â‰¤ Y n â‰¤ EX +  Ïƒ ( X)/ âˆš n) â€¢ Thus : rv Y n is with % probability not further than  Ïƒ ( X)/ âˆš n away from EX â€¢ Thus : [ Y n -  Ïƒ ( X)/ âˆš n, Y n +  Ïƒ ( X)/ âˆš n] is a % confidence interval for EX â€¢ However : Ïƒ ( X) is usual unknown â€¢ Estimator Ïƒ  ( X): s  = Î£ i (X i â€“ Y n )  / (n - ) Confidence interval = P( Y n -  Ïƒ ( X)/ âˆš n â‰¤ EX â‰¤ Y n +  Ïƒ ( X)/ âˆš n) The n -  ensures that E [s  ] = Ïƒ  ( X) % confidence interval of Y n (More precise:  percentile of standard normal dist =  instead )  â€¢ Thus : CI of EX is [ Y n -  s / âˆš n, Y n + s / âˆš n] â€¢ But s is rv :  â†’  percentile of t - dist with n -  â€œdegrees of freedomâ€ â‰ˆ  (for n large enough) â€¢ Note : to double precision,  times as many experiments necessary! Confidence interval EX â€œ% of the CIs generated will contain EXâ€  Example â€¢  simulations: â€“ Average =  â€“ Standard deviation estimation =  â€“ % CI = [ -  *  / ,  +  *  / ] = [, ] Gives a â€œwell - founded ideaâ€ about how far our estimate is from the true EX  Discrete - event simulation Motivation: simulation of real - life processes that are too complex to capture in r( X) (or r( X, Ï€) ) Examples: Afbeeldingsresultaat voor queue If only they used some simulationâ€¦ Service system with customers Factory with work - in - process Other examples: customers in sales funnel, disease progression in patients (Sometimes called â€œmicro - simulationâ€ or â€œdigital twinâ€)  Discrete - event simulation (DES) â€¢ Simulates a process over time using a discrete sequence of events over time â€¢ Keeps track of the state of the process â€¢ At each event the state is updated â€¢ State unchanged between consecutive events ïƒ  So repeatedly jump to next event and process â€¢ Repeat simulation and keep track of performance measure(s) â€¢ Statistical analysis of performance measures  Time (min) # customers in queue           State Event: A service ready Event: New customer arrives DES example â€¢ Consider the following queue â€¢ DES idea: germany, kiosk, line Exponential interarrival times between customers The service time is lognormally distributed     DES example Queue with exponential interarrival times and lognormal service time distribution â€œCurrent event is a departure or an arrival at an empty systemâ€  Determine next event:  Update time:  Update state:  Update next arrival time:  Update next departure time:  DES Tooling â€¢ Programming in any programming language â€“ Libraries with random number generators and event list handling â€“ Appropriate for (and even origin of) object - oriented programming â€¢ Graphical DES software  promodelscreenshot Graphical DES software â€¢ Graphical interfaces â€¢ Drag and drop modeling ï¼‹ quick in modeling ï¼‹ easy to present âˆ’ slow in calculation âˆ’ lacks flexibility âˆ’ expensive Screen Shot -- at  png  Screen Shot -- at  png Many tools Screen Shot -- at  png  promodelscreenshot Arena â€¢ Simple process : wwwyoutubecom/watch?v=dlbWWFens â€¢ For a free restricted student version : https://wwwarenasimulationcom/academic/students  Performance â€¢ Often an average over time â€¢ Example: average # in queue per day â€¢ CI as for Monte Carlo simulation â€¢ Variability decreases with length of horizon â€“ Slowly because of long - term correlations  â€¢ Expectation and variance of random variables ( rvâ€™s ) in simulation context â€¢ Simulation of a random variable â€¢ Discrete - event simulation â€¢ Statistical analysis of simulation results Recap goals today

abstract: Statistics, Simulation & Optimization Lecture  Joost Berkhout, VU Remark about Assignment  Exercise  a): it may theoretically be the case that you need more than  simulations, so therefore, I changed the way of question asking: Was: â€œ Simulate the revenue for every price  times to determine the optimum price with a  significance level using an appropriate test â€ Now: â€œSimulate the revenue for every price often enough (eg,  times ) to determine the optimum price with a  significance level using an appropriate testâ€  Program â€¢ Lecture : Linear optimization â€¢ Lecture : Advanced modeling â€¢ Lecture : Solvers, heuristics, complexity â€¢ Lecture : Simulation â€¢ Lecture : Simulation optimization â€¢ Lecture : Dynamic optimization â€¢ Lecture : W rap - up  Today Real - life problem Input â€œRepresented byâ€ - Random parameters X - Decision Ï€ âˆˆ S Problem form: max E[ r( X, Ï€ ) ] st Ï€ âˆˆ S Model r() Output r( X, Ï€ ) Rv r(X,Ï€) can only be simulated Simulation - based optimization  Goal today Introduction to simulation - based optimization: â€¢ Main challenges â€¢ Overview of solving strategies in different settings  â€¢ More complicated than deterministic optimization â€“ No optimality/performance guarantees â€“ Might overestimate optimum â€“ Simulation might be time - consuming (especially when simulating complex processes = discrete - event simulation) â€¢ Example:  values for Ï€, E[ r( X, Ï€ ) ] close for different Ï€ but r( X, Ï€ ) highly variable â€¢ For practical reasons often a limited simulation budget (eg, max K simulations) â€¢ Challenge: how to spend this budget efficiently? â€¢ Even more challenging when feasible region S random (eg, of form E[g(X, Ï€)] â‰¤ ) Simulation optimization  Simulation optimization Roughly  types of problems: â€¢ |S| =  â€¢ S small â€“ â€œranking and selectionâ€ â€¢ S big or countable but discrete (eg, a grid) â€“ local search â€¢ S continuous â€“ gradient methods S  Comparing scenarios â€¢ Using simulation, goal is not EX but comparing two scenarios X and X â€™ : Is X better or worse than X â€™ ? â€¢ Random profit = r( X , Ï€ ) = min( X , Ï€ ) -  Ï€ â€¢ Ï€ âˆˆ S = {, , , â€¦, } â€¢ Simulation - optimization problem : max E[min( X , Ï€ )] -  Ï€ , for Ï€ âˆˆ S Gerelateerde afbeelding = E[ r( X , Ï€ ) ]  Ranking and selection â€¢ Simulation budget m : m runs possible â€¢ Option  : simulate every solution m /|S| times and return best solution â€¢ However, suppose that after < m runs we have the following % CIs for E[ r( X , Ï€ ) ] Are these outer solutions still worthwhile to simulate? Idea R&S Option : Discard statistically â€œbadâ€ solutions more quickly and focus on better ones  Ranking and selection â€¢ Ï€ âˆˆ S with S finite and small â€¢ Simulation budget m : m runs possible â€¢ Option  :  Simulate every solution a number of times and calculate averages and variances  Perform all pairwise t - tests* for ( Ï€ , Ï€â€™ ) to see if Ï€ is significantly â€œoutperformedâ€ by a Ï€â€™  Discard outperformed solutions  Divide remaining simulation budget over the remaining candidate solutions & return best * Because Ï€ can be outperformed by |S| -  other solutions a t - test is applied with â€œconservativelyâ€ significance level ğ›¼*  R&S Option  Testing â€¢ We want to be careful to not discard the best solution with significance level ğ›¼ â€¢ So for each Ï€ , test ğ»( Ï€ ): Ï€ is best solution ğ»( Ï€ ) : Ï€ is not best solution â€¢ Per Ï€ , t - test for all Ï€â€™ â‰  Ï€ with significance level ğ›¼* ğ»( Ï€,Ï€â€™): Ï€ is not worse than Ï€â€™ ğ»( Ï€,Ï€â€™): Ï€ is worse than Ï€â€™ â€¢ If ğ»( Ï€,Ï€â€™) is rejected for a Ï€ â€™ : discard Ï€ Multiple testing problem At least on Ï€â€™ â‰  Ï€ is better |S| -  t - tests (reject ğ»( Ï€ ))  Choosing significance level ğ›¼* â€¢ |S| -  chances of falsely discarding Ï€, so choose ğ›¼* such that overall significance level is ğ›¼ â€¢ Interpretations:  - ğ›¼= probability of not rejecting a true ğ»( Ï€ )  - ğ›¼* = probability of not rejecting a true ğ»( Ï€,Ï€â€™) â€¢ When ğ»( Ï€ ) is true , the probability of not rejecting any (true) ğ»( Ï€,Ï€â€™) for Ï€â€™ â‰  Ï€ is ( - ğ›¼* ) |S| -  â€¢ So choose ğ›¼* so that (  - ğ›¼* ) |S| -  =  - ğ›¼, ie, ğ›¼* =  - ğ‘†âˆ’-ğ›¼ Å idÃ¡k correction  R&S Option  Example newsvendor problem â€¢ After simulating each solution n =  times in Step : â€¢ Which solutions to discard in Step  with significance level ğ›¼= ? abstract: Statistics, Simulation & Optimization Lecture  Joost Berkhout, VU Some announcements: â€¢ Updated slide  from Lecture  slides: x  =  (instead of ) â€¢ Updated some minor typos and added some comments in Lecture  slides â€¢ A kindly request to fill in the evaluation forms next week during/after the exam and hand them in afterwards This will be used to improve the course thanks!  Program â€¢ Lecture : Linear optimization â€¢ Lecture : Advanced modeling â€¢ Lecture : Solvers, heuristics, complexity â€¢ Lecture : Simulation â€¢ Lecture : Simulation optimization â€¢ Lecture : Dynamic optimization â€¢ Lecture : W rap - up  Today â€¢ Reinforcement learning â€¢ Wrap - up â€¢ Animal feed p roduction planning optimization  Last lecture Stochastic dynamic optimization (DO) problems: â€¢ Decision Ï€ âˆˆ S is a sequence of decisions over time: Ï€ = ( Ï€  , Ï€  , â€¦, Ï€ T ) â€¢ X t = random state of the process at time t â€¢ Transitions are random with known probabilities: p t (x, Ï€ t ,y ) = probability of going from state x to y when choosing Ï€ t at time t â€¢ The objective function is of the form r(Ï€ ) = Î£ t = T E[ r t ( X t ,Ï€ t )] Real - life problem Input â€œRepresented byâ€ - Random parameters - Decision Ï€ âˆˆ S Problem form: max r( Ï€ ) st Ï€ âˆˆ S Model r() Output r( Ï€ ) Ï€ t is decision at time t Expected reward at time t when choosing Ï€ t at state X t  Reinforcement learning (RL) â€¢ In practice: transition probabilities unknown â€¢ Process information becomes available while operating the system â€¢ Examples: â€“ Introduction of a new medicine â€“ New product demand in case of the newsvendor problem â€“ Price elasticity in hotel industry â€¢ The challenge is how to balance: i Exploration : Gaining new information ii Exploitation : Maximizing rewards with current information â€¢ Framework for this trade - off: Reinforcement learning  Medicine problem â€¢ Introduction of a new medicine â€¢ Old medicine is well - known and has success - probability s â€¢ New medicine has unknown success - probability modeled by a uniform distribution [, ] â€¢ T patients to be cured â€¢ Goal: cure as many of the T patients Gerelateerde afbeelding Afbeeldingsresultaat voor waiting patients cartoon    â€¦ T  DO model medicine problem â€¢ Patient t is the t - th arriving sick patient â€¢ State = (m, n) is defined as: â€“ m successful treatments with new medicine â€“ n unsuccessful treatments with new medicine â€¢ V t (m, n) = maximum expected successful treatments of patients t, t + , â€¦, T â€¢ p (m, n) = expected success probability when choosing new medicine that has been applied m + n times with m successes â€¢ By assumption initially: p (, ) = EX =  X uniform distr [,] Gerelateerde afbeelding  Success probability in medicine problem â€¢ Define random variable X m,n = true success probability of new medicine after m + n trials with m successes â€¢ p (m, n) = E X m,n â€¢ Bayesian inference states: X m,n ~ Beta(m + , n + ) â€¢ Result: p (m, n) = E X m,n = (m+)/(m+n+) (note that this matches intuition) â€œClosed â€ within class of Beta distributions: Beta(successes+,failures+) Gerelateerde afbeelding  Bayesian inference Screen Shot -- at  png Experiment Success Failure Screen Shot -- at  png Screen Shot -- at  png Screen Shot -- at  png Screen Shot -- at  png Screen Shot -- at  png Pdf of success probability at start = uniform on [,] (â€œno infoâ€) The (â€œposteriorâ€) pdfâ€™s of the true success probability are updated with each new experiment (= info) X , ~ Beta(,), E X , =  Alternative to randomized trials â€“ applicable to other areas such as online marketing Experiment Success Failure Success Failure X , ~ Beta(,), E X , = / X , ~ Beta(,), E X , = / X , ~ Beta(,), E X , = / X , ~ Beta(,), E X , = / X , ~ Beta(,), E X , = /  â€œNewâ€ DO model medicine problem â€¢ V t (m, n) = maximum expected successful V t (m , n) = treatments of patients t, t + , â€¦, T â€¢ Goal : Find V  (, ) â€¢ Decision: Ï€ t âˆŠ {,},  = if patient t gets old medicine,  else â€¢ Optimality equation : for m, n âˆŠ { ,,â€¦,T} V t (m, n) = max{ p (m, n) ( + V t+ (m+, n)) + ( - p (m, n) ) V t+ (m, n+); s ( + V t+ (m, n)) + ( - s ) V t+ (m, n) } â€¢ Boundary conditions : for m, n âˆŠ {,,â€¦,T } V T+ (m, n) =  â€œOldâ€ Gerelateerde afbeelding  Balancing between exploration and exploitation â€¢ Suppose that true success probability q of new medicine is s < q < : â€“ It still may happen that state (, ) is reached, indicating that the new medicine seems to be bad â€“ However, RL may still consider the new medicine if there are enough remaining patients so that it may be beneficial to try the new medicine a few more times â€¢ Problem: State space explosion (it weighs all experiment possibilities) â€¢ RL research focuses on approximatively solving these enormous problems Gerelateerde afbeelding Using machine learning techniques  Reinforcement learning â€¢ Hot topic in artificial intelligence â€¢ Example application domains Afbeeldingsresultaat voor robotics mars Robotics Automatic negotiation Afbeeldingsresultaat voor AlphaGO Playing â€œgamesâ€ (Click here for an example with surprising results) Afbeeldingsresultaat voor negotiation\  Today â€¢ Reinforcement learning â€¢ Wrap - up â€¢ Animal feed p roduction planning optimization  Using data and predictions: What should we do? More value, but less used* Statistics part * Source: renowned consultancy company Gartner, see here and here Simulation & optimization part Less value, but more used The big picture  Optimization process â€¢ Phase  : Problem identification and study â€“ Problem type? â€“ Benefits of solving? â€“ What would a solution look like? â€“ Ethics? (â€œ With great power comes great responsibilityâ€) â€¢ Phase  : Solution development â€“ Existing methods? â€“ Modeling (see optimization model decision tree next slide) â€“ Data analysis â€¢ Phase  : Testing â€“ Statistical analysis of solving historical instances â€¢ Phase  : Implementation â€“ User interface â€“ Psychological effects users Iterating phases  Optimization model decision tree dynamic problem with state - dependent actions? (stochastic) dynamic optimization objective for given solution can be calculated? simulation optimization problem with known algorithm? (non)linear optimization formulation? adaptable to local search or other heuristic? YES NO only simulation YES YES apply algorithm NO NO YES YES apply (non)linear optimization NO apply local search/heuristic no method available â€“ decompose?  Today â€¢ Reinforcement learning â€¢ Wrap - up â€¢ Animal feed p roduction planning optimization  Productionplanning optimization in the animal feed industry Joint project with : Jan Stolze , Siem Broersen & Viktor Klein (ENGIE) prof dr Rob van der Mei & dr Eric Pauwels (CWI) Wouter Berkelmans (VU) Public private partnership between : C:\Users\MQ\Downloads\Presentatie Techport (--)\CWI_Logo_Croppedjpg C:\Users\MQ\Downloads\Presentatie Techport (--)\ENGIE_logo_croppedjpg Afbeeldingsresultaat voor vu university  Content â€¢ Problem description â€¢ Approach â€¢ Current results â€¢ Concluding remarks  Scheduling in Animal - Feed Plants Gerelateerde afbeelding Afbeeldingsresultaat voor silos World - wide: ,,,, kg animal - feed each year , plants in  countries  plants in the Netherlands  Production Process  Production aspects: â€¢ Customer order due dates â€¢ Contamination â€¢ Changeover time between products (eg, sieve change) â€¢ Finite silo capacities â€¢ Stochastic production durations with season trends â€¢ â€¦ Production Scheduling Problem How to â€œefficientlyâ€ schedule the customer orders? Minimize customer weighted tardiness and makespan  Production Scheduling Problem Current situation: planners â€˜schedule by handâ€™ As a result: time - consuming and opportunity loss (inflexible and â€˜big dataâ€™ unused) Trend: mass - customization & plant automation ( ïƒ  big data)  Project Objective: Optimization (algorithm) Customer orders (due dates) Objective (min due date exceedances & makespan ) Historical data Production process and restrictions Scheduling advice  Approach  Study of production process  Modeling of production scheduling problem Crucial : an accurate model of the process  Model testing at pilot plant  near Eindhoven A lot of technical details â€¦  Modeling phase in short: Afbeeldingsresultaat voor gurobi Simplification: Integer linear optimization (ILO) problem: ILO implementation: Accuracy testing: Solve MILP: Schedule advice:  Modeling schedulingproblem Scheduling problem is modeled as a Integer linear optimization (ILO) problem Objective Minimize tardiness and makespan Constraints Production schedules  Reasons for ILO:  Formulating an ILO forces you to dive into problem fundamentals  It is flexible: easy to add another restriction in modeling phase  Capabilities ILO solvers (eg, Gurobi or CPLEX) and modern PCâ€™s  ILO finds an optimal solution (for comparison with heuristics)  ILO useful as basis for a heuristic for larger instances Note: ILO not capable of solving really large instances (>  hours) Standard ILO formulation:  Comparison to realized schedules for  instances of  hours when solving for  seconds A ll schedules found respect the due dates Current results WED: Fixing customer order sequence in MILP based on due dates  Concluding remarks â€¢ Testing results look promising (efficiency gain of %) â€¢ Model runs now in pilot plant : propose schedules, get feedback and test real - life performance â€¢ Enhance optimization strategy for larger instances: ï‚§ Reducing ILO solution space by using common practice ï‚§ (Meta) - heuristics ïƒ  evolutionary algorithms  Thanks for your attention! Any questions? Mail: jberkhout@cwinl Afbeeldingsresultaat voor silos Afbeeldingsresultaat voor boerenbond deurne Afbeeldingsresultaat voor koe in de wei

outcomes obtained by repeating an experiment over and over, eg, throwing a die many times A sample is a set of values (randomly) selected from a population The population has a certain distribution, called the population distribution From the sample we want to gain information about this unknown population distribution SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish Types of data summaries A good summary of a data set shows the relevant information in a data set It can exist of numerical summaries (what it estimates/investigates) sample mean (population mean) sample median (population median) sample standard deviation (population standard deviation) sample variance (population variance) sample correlation(s) (population correlation(s)) graphical summaries histogram (probability density or probability mass) empirical distribution function (cumulative probability function) boxplot (assess symmetry) scatter plot(s) (assess relations) SSO Lecture parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish Example â€” expensescrime () An example of a multivariate data set, multiple measurements per â€˜objectâ€™ The data expensescrime were obtained to determine factors related to state expenditures on fighting criminality (courts, police, etc) The variables are: state (indicating the state in the USA), expend (state expenditures on fighting criminality in $), bad (number of persons under judicial supervision), crime (crime rate per ), lawyers (number of lawyers in the state), employ (number of persons employed in the state) and pop (population of the state in ) > head(expensescrime) state expend bad crime lawyers employ pop  AK        AL        AR        AZ        CA        CO       Apart from numerical and graphical summaries of the columns separately, we can consider bivariate summaries to see the relation between pairs of columns SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish Correlation and scatter plot () The correlation between two variables quantifies the linear relation between the two variables âˆ’âˆ’âˆ’âˆ’cor = variable variable âˆ’âˆ’âˆ’âˆ’âˆ’cor = âˆ’variable variable âˆ’Correlation values: +: perfect linear relation (straight line) with positive slope â€“: perfect linear relation (straight line) with negative slope : no linear relation (but maybe some other relation?!) SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish Correlation and scatter plot () Example of two variables that have correlation close to , but a clear relation: âˆ’âˆ’cor variable  Such a figure is called a scatter plot of variable  (vertical) versus variable  (horizontal) Complement graphical summaries with numerical summaries and vice versa SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish Example â€” expensescrime () The correlation between all pairs of variables, excluding the first column of state names: > round(cor(expensescrime[,-]),) expend bad crime lawyers employ pop expend       bad       crime       lawyers       employ       pop       Ingredients of R-code: expensescrime[,-] removes column  from expensescrime cor(expensescrime[,-]) produces pairwise correlations between remaining columns round(cor(expensescrime[,-]),) rounds the numbers to  decimals SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish Example â€” expensescrime () The scatter plots of all pairs of variables, excluding the first column of state names: > pairs(expensescrime[,-]) expendbadcrimelawyersemploypop SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish Example â€” expensescrime () The scatter plots of only the variables expend, crime, employ, pop: SSO Lecture   /  >pairs(expensescrime[,c(,,,)]) expendcrimeemploypopexpensescrime[,c(,,,)]selects columns , ,  and   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish QQ-plots and exploring distributions SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish Goal of exploring distributions and scale If we know or may assume that a sample comes from some (standard) distribution, perhaps with unknown parameter(s), then the summary could be, eg, the data follow a normal distribution, and we then estimate/test the parameters Î¼ and  we know whether statistical methods that require a normal distribution of the data are applicable We will only discuss investigating normality, ie, whether the population distribution is normal SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish All normal distributions are similar Two normal distributions with different Î¼ (mean) and  (standard deviation) are similar in the following way âˆ’normal(,) and normal(,) density(,) (,) âˆ’âˆ’âˆ’normal(densityâˆ’All normal distributions have the same bell shape The normal density function is  eâˆ’  (xâˆ’Î¼)/ pÎ¼,(x)= p  SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish QQ-plots A normal QQ-plot (or normal probability plot) can reveal whether data (approximately) follows a normal distribution For a sample of size n it plots the ordered data x(), x(),, x(n) with x()  x()   x(n) versus the values n,, n,,, n,n that are typical for ordered values from a normal population A fraction of i/n of the population is smaller than the i/n-quantile n,i If the points are approximately on a straight line, then the data can be assumed to be sampled from a normal population with some values Î¼ and , which need to be estimated (Pay special attention to the corners!) SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish Examples Some QQ-plots (qqnorm) of the income data and the expensescrime data: whiteFrequencye+expendFrequencyexpensescrime$crimeFrequencyâˆ’âˆ’e+e+e+qqnorm(income$white) Theoretical QuantilesSample Quantilesâˆ’âˆ’qqnorm(expensescrime$Theoretical QuantilesSample Quantilesâˆ’SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish to finish SSO Lecture   /   course parameters distributions summarizing data QQ-plots to finish To wrap up Today we discussed probability distributions summarizing data QQ-plots In the first assignment you will practice these topics Make neat and concise reports of the assignments Next time estimation and statistical tests SSO Lecture   /

distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish The sample mean and its distribution The sample mean of a sample X,, Xn of sample size n is X = Â¯ X  n Xi n i= We can consider the sampling distribution of the sample mean When the sample is taken from the normal(Î¼,  X has exactly the normal(Î¼, /n) distribution Â¯ ) distribution, then the sample  mean Â¯X hasapproximately thenormal(Î¼, When the sample is taken from some other distribution with expectation Î¼ and variance   , then the sample mean  /n) distribution because of the Central Limit Theorem In both cases the mean varies less than the individual observations: the p standard deviation  is replaced by / n SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Examples of sample mean Examples of distributions of X (black) and distribution of sample mean for sample sizes n = , n =  and n =  âˆ’âˆ’âˆ’normal(exp(poisson(The larger the sample size, the lower the variance in the distribution of the sample mean SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Standardizing the mean A normally distributed random variable X with mean Î¼ and standard deviation  can be standardized into a standard N(, ) variable by X âˆ’ Î¼ Z =  If X  N(Î¼, ) then Z  N(, ) This is just applying the right scaling and shifting as in slide  of last week (â€œAll normal distributions are similarâ€) Standardizing the sample mean yields p XÂ¯ âˆ’ Î¼ n(XÂ¯ âˆ’ Î¼) Z = p =  N(, ) / n  SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish The t-distribution In a real data set X,, Xn the population standard deviation  is unknown and needs to be estimated by the sample standard deviation s This uncertainty influences the distribution of the sample mean The random variable Â¯ X âˆ’ Î¼ p s/ n does not have the normal N(, ) distribution Instead, it has a t-distribution with n âˆ’  degrees of freedom SSO / Lecture   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish estimation SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Estimation â€“ the concept Suppose we assume that our population of interest has a certain distribution with an unknown parameter, eg its mean Î¼ or a fraction p A point estimate (puntschatting) for the unknown parameter is a function of (only) the observed data (x,, xn) We denote estimators by a hat: Î¼Ë†, pË†, etc Examples: Â¯ Î¼Ë†= X pË† is the sample proportion A confidence interval (betrouwbaarheidsinterval) for the unknown parameter is an interval based on (only) the observed data (x,, xn) that contains the true value of the parameter with a certain level of confidence SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Estimating the mean () For given random variables X,, Xn from the normal(Î¼, ) distribution, we have that XÂ¯  N(Î¼, /n) Define the following (upper) quantile of the standard normal distribution: z =qnorm(-alpha), such that P(Z  z ) = for Z  N(, ) Then we have the following probability: ô€€€   âˆ’ = P Î¼ âˆ’ z / p XÂ¯  Î¼ + z / p nn ô€€€   = P âˆ’ z / p XÂ¯ âˆ’ Î¼  z / p nn ô€€€  = P âˆ’ z / p Î¼ âˆ’ XÂ¯  z / p nn ô€€€Â¯   = PX âˆ’ z / p Î¼  XÂ¯ + z / p nn SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Estimating the mean () We ended up with X âˆ’ z /    Î¼  XÂ¯ + z /   âˆ’ = P p n p n In other words: the probability that the true mean Î¼ lies in the interval  pn [XÂ¯ âˆ’ z /  Â¯ X + z / ] p n , equals  âˆ’ We denote such a confidence interval as: Â¯ X Â± z /  p n The confidence level of this interval is  âˆ’ SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Estimating the mean () If the standard deviation  is unknown, we estimate it by s and the confidence interval is based on a t-distribution and t-quantile t =qt(-alpha,df=n-) The t confidence interval for Î¼ is: s Â¯ X Â± t / p n The confidence level of this interval is  âˆ’ Remark In real data sets this interval is (nearly) always used, since it does not make the assumption of known  SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Example â€“ heights of women () Consider the data of heights (in cm) of  women womenwomenFrequencyâˆ’âˆ’âˆ’Normal QuantilesSample Quantiles > women=scan("lengthswomentxt") Read  items > par(mfrow=c(,)) > hist(women) > qqnorm(women) > n=length(women) >n []  > m=mean(women) >m []  > s=sd(women) >s []  > t=qt(,df=n-) >t []  > c(m-t*s/sqrt(n),m+t*s/sqrt(n)) []   SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Example â€“ heights of women () We used /=, so the confidence level is  âˆ’ = âˆ’  =  We derived the following % confidence interval for the mean height of women: [, ] cm SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Margin of error for the mean The ( âˆ’ )-confidence interval for Î¼ Â¯X Â± z / pn or sÂ¯X Â± t / p n The margin of error is  z / pn or st / p n Note  If we take larger n, the confidence interval will be smaller (shorter) In other words: we gain more accuracy at the same confidence level Note  If  (or s) is smaller, the confidence interval will be smaller (shorter) In other words: this yields more accuracy at the same confidence level Note  If we take bigger , the confidence interval will be smaller (shorter) Be careful: more accuracy at the cost of a lower confidence level SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Minimal sample size Question How big should the sample size be in order to obtain a margin of error of E? Answer We need to solve n from  s z / p = E or t / p = E nn This yields p z / p t /s n = or n = EE (z /) (t /)s n = or n = E E Remark For large n we have t /  z / and s   SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Example â€“ heights of women () Question How big should the sample size in the women heights data be to obtain E= mm at a confidence level of %? Answer We have E =cm,   , z / = which yields ()() n = =   In words: we should include at least  women to have a confidence interval of length at most cm (note that the interval length is  Ã— E) SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Estimating a proportion Suppose we want to estimate a population proportion p, based on a sample The point estimate for p will be the sample proportion pË† Write q = âˆ’ p and qË†= âˆ’ pË† The confidence interval for p with confidence level  âˆ’ is given by r pË†qË† pË† Â± z / n (This is based on the normal approximation of the binomial distribution, Sec ) The margin of error and minimal sample size are therefore r pË†qË† z /pË†qË† E = z / and n = nE SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Example â€“ trains in time Question Suppose we want to take a sample amongst trains of NS to estimate the fraction p of trains that arrive in time In august  this fraction was  (according to wwwnsnl) We want to set up a % confidence interval for p with length at most % How many trains should we include in the sample? Answer A length of % means  Ã— E = and E = Furthermore pË†=, so qË†= For a % interval we have z / = qnorm()= The minimal sample size is z /pË†qË† () Ã—  Ã—  n = = =  E () which is found in R by qnorm()Ë†**/()Ë† In words: we should include at least  trains to have a % confidence interval of length at most % SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish hypothesis testing SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Testing â€“ the concept () In a hypothesis test or test of significance (hypothese toets), we have two claims, the null hypothesis H and the alternative hypothesis H, which do not overlap The goal is to draw some conclusion about the correctness of the two claims The claim of interest is usually represented by H A test has two possible outcomes: the strong outcome: H is rejected, and H is assumed to be true the weak outcome: H is not rejected, (H isnâ€™t either!) Example H: The mean income of inhabitants of Amsterdam is lower than e (the mean income of the Netherlands) H: the mean income of inhabitants of Amsterdam is higher than e SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Testing â€“ the concept () In order to perform the test, one needs a test statistic, which summarizes the data in a relevant way The H is rejected if the value of the test statistic is too far away from what is expected under the H Example (incomes Amsterdam) Given a sample of incomes in Amsterdam a sensible test statistic would be the sample mean The value of the test statistic is converted into a p-value The p-value expresses the probability of getting a value of the test statistic at least as extreme as in the data, assuming that H is true When this p-value is below the chosen significance level (eg = ) the outcome is: reject H (strong outcome) If the p-value is bigger, then we do not reject H (weak outcome) SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Example â€“ Amsterdam incomes () (Fictive) data on  incomes in Amsterdam amsterdamamsterdamFrequencyâˆ’QuantilesSample Quantiles Assuming that the underlying distribution of incomes is normal (Î¼,) seems ok for this dataset We take  unknown We test H : Î¼  Î¼ =  versus H : Î¼>Î¼ =  The value of XÂ¯ is relevant for H, so base test statistic on XÂ¯ SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Example â€“ Amsterdam incomes () The test statistic is Â¯ X âˆ’ Î¼ T = p s/ n which has the t-distribution with n âˆ’  degrees of freedom, at the border of H and H, ie for Î¼ = Î¼ (slide ) > m=mean(amsterdam) > s=sd(amsterdam) > n=length(amsterdam) > t=(m-)/(s/sqrt(n)) >t []  > -pt(,df=n-) []  The p-value is  Conclusion? âˆ’âˆ’âˆ’pâˆ’SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish The t-test The t-test is for testing the population mean Î¼ of a normal population i H : Î¼  Î¼ versus H : Î¼>Î¼ (ttest(data,mu=Î¼,alt="g")) ii H : Î¼  Î¼ versus H : Î¼<Î¼ (ttest(data,mu=Î¼,alt="l")) iii H : Î¼ = Î¼ versus H : Î¼ = Î¼ (ttest(data,mu=Î¼)) In all  cases the test statistic is Â¯ X âˆ’ Î¼ T = p s/ n which has the t-distribution with n âˆ’  degrees of freedom, at the border of H and H (ie for Î¼ = Î¼) The p-value for observed value t of test statistic is i p = P(T  t) under H ii p = P(T  t) under H ô€€€ iii p = Ã— min P(T  t), P(T  t) under H SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Example â€“ Amsterdam incomes () The t-test on the Amsterdam data in R, using ttest: > ttest(amsterdam,mu=,alt="g") One Sample t-test data: amsterdam t = , df = , p-value =  alternative hypothesis: true mean is greater than   percent confidence interval:  Inf sample estimates: mean of x  Confidence interval [, +) is also given in the above output But why is Inf in it? SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Example â€“ trains in Amsterdam () In a (fictive) sample amongst  trains arriving at Amsterdam Central station we measure a sample proportion of pË†= (/) trains arriving in time We want to test whether this is significantly lower than the reported % for The Netherlands: H : p   versus H : p <  This is a binomial sample with n =  and p unknown One can find the exact p-value, assuming p =, from the binomial(,) Alternatively, one can use the normal approximation to the binomial distribution Here the p-value is for finding at most  out of  > pbinom(,size=,p=) []  Conclusion? SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish The binomial test The binomial test is for testing the population proportion p i H : p  p versus H : p > p (binomtest(number,n,p=p,alt="g")) ii H : p  p versus H : p < p (binomtest(number,n,p=p,alt="l")) iii H : p = p versus H : p = p (binomtest(number,n,p=p)) In all  cases the test statistic is the number of â€œsuccessesâ€ in the sample, which has a binomial(n, p) distribution at the border of H and H (ie for p = p) As for the t-test, the p-value is calculated one-sided or two-sided SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish Example â€“ trains in Amsterdam () > binomtest(,n=,p=,alt="l") Exact binomial test data:  and  number of successes = , number of trials = , p-value =  alternative hypothesis: true probability of success is less than   percent confidence interval:   sample estimates: probability of success  SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish to finish SSO Lecture   /   distribution sample mean parameters estimation hypothesis testing to finish To wrap up Today we discussed distribution of sample mean estimation hypothesis testing Next time more on statistical tests (two sample tests, nonparametric tests) SSO Lecture   /

abstract: SSO, Lecture  SSO, Lecture  Eduard Belitser VU Amsterdam  one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Overview     recap one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk test two samples tests two means (independent samples) two means (matched pairs) two proportions nonparametric tests sign test Wilcoxon signed-rank test Wilcoxon rank-sum test SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up recap: t-test and binomial test SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Recap tests and p-values A test of significance yields a conclusion about the null hypothesis H versus the alternative hypothesis H The H is either rejected or not The conclusion of the test is based on the p-value, expressing the likelihood of the observed data under the H If the p-value is lower than a certain threshold (the significance level of the test), then H is rejected The p-value is calculated from a test statistic T, which summarizes the data in a (for the test) relevant way In order to compute the p-value, one needs to know the distribution of T under H The p-value can be either one-sided or two-sided: pright = P(T  t) under H pleft = P(T  t) under H ô€€€ ptwoâˆ’sided = Ã— min pleft, pright under H SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Type I and type II error A hypothesis test has two possible outcomes: reject H or do not reject H Therefore, one can make two types of errors: Type I error reject H while it is true Type II error not reject H while it is false Which error is worse? In a type I error the conclusion is really wrong In a type II error there is no conclusion, whereas we could have drawn one The significance level of a test limits the probability of a type I error to A test has high power if the probability of a type II error is small The sample size influences the power: higher sample size yields higher power Asymmetric treatment of the errors: rejecting H is a strong conclusion, so the claim of interest is usually represented by H SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Recap t-test for the mean of one sample Setting: a sample X,, Xn  N(Î¼, ), test about the mean Î¼ () () = = Hypotheses: H : Î¼  Î¼ versus H : Î¼>Î¼  < Test statistic: T = Xs/ âˆ’ pÎ¼ n  Distribution of T under H: t-distribution with n âˆ’  degrees of freedom In R: ttest(data,mu=Î¼,alt=) SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Recap binomial and (appr) normal tests for a proportion Setting: X  Bin(n, p), eg, the number of successes in n trials, p is the success proportion (or the probability of success) We want to test about p () () = = Hypotheses: H : p  p versus H : p > p  < pË†âˆ’p Test statistic: X or T = p , where pË†= X/n p(âˆ’p)/n Distribution under H: X  Bin(n, p) (exactly) or T  N(, ) (approx) In R: binomtest(number,n,p=p,alt=) proptest(number,n,p=p,alt=) SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ trains on time () We test whether the â€œon-time fractionâ€ amongst trains arriving in Amsterdam is % In our (fictive) sample amongst  trains  trains are on time The exact binomial test: > binomtest(,,p=) Exact binomial test data:  and  number of successes = , number of trials = , p-value =  alternative hypothesis: true probability of success is not equal to   percent confidence interval:   sample estimates: probability of success  SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ trains on time () The approximate test: > proptest(,,p=) -sample proportions test with continuity correction data:  out of , null probability  X-squared = , df = , p-value =  alternative hypothesis: true p is not equal to   percent confidence interval:   sample estimates: p  The p-values in both tests are smaller than  (but different), and the conclusion is the same: reject H SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ trains on time () The influence of the sample size: if we had found  trains arriving in time amongst  trains: > binomtest(,,p=) Exact binomial test data:  and  number of successes = , number of trials = , p-value = e- > proptest(,,p=) -sample proportions test with continuity correction data:  out of , null probability  X-squared = , df = , p-value < e- e- = âˆ’ =, e-= Finding the same deviation from H in more data is more convincing, ie yields a lower p-value SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Shapiro-Wilk test for normality SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Shapiro Wilk test for normality Setting: A sample X,, Xn from an unkown distribution P Hypotheses: H : P is a normal distribution versus H : P is not a normal Test statistic: with certain constants a,, an, ô€€€Pn  i= ai X(i) W = Pn  (, ] i=(Xi âˆ’ X) Distribution of W under H: known, but complicated to write down H is rejected for â€œsmallâ€ values of W It is always the left-sided test In R: shapirotest(x) Note: this test complements the graphical check by a normal QQ-plot SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up two means: independent or matched samples SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ incomes of Amsterdam and Rotterdam () (Fictive) data on  incomes in Amsterdam and  incomes in Rotterdam amsterdamrotterdamâˆ’âˆ’QQplot amsterdamTheoretical QuantilesSample Quantilesâˆ’Question: is the mean income the same in Amsterdam and Rotterdam? Remark This is a fictive data set, real incomes are not symmetrically distributed SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ incomes of Amsterdam and Rotterdam () Compare sample means and standard deviations: > mean(amsterdam) []  > sd(amsterdam) []  > length(amsterdam) []  > mean(rotterdam) []  > sd(rotterdam) []  > length(rotterdam) []  > shapirotest(amsterdam) Shapiro-Wilk normality test data: amsterdam W = , p-value =  > shapirotest(rotterdam) Shapiro-Wilk normality test data: rotterdam W = , p-value =  We will use the t-test for testing the difference in means for two independent samples SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up t-test for two means of two independent samples Setting: Two samples: X,, Xn  N(Î¼,) and Y,, Yn  N(Î¼,) We want to test about the difference in mean Î¼ âˆ’ Î¼ () () = = Hypotheses: H : Î¼ âˆ’ Î¼   versus H : Î¼ âˆ’ Î¼ >   < Xâˆ’YÂ¯ Test statistic: T = q Â¯ s s  + n n Distribution of T under H: approx t-distribution with df (R computes df approximately) degrees of freedom In R: ttest(data,data,mu=,alt=) SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ incomes of Amsterdam and Rotterdam () The t-test for two independent samples (Amsterdam and Rotterdam): > ttest(amsterdam,rotterdam) Welch Two Sample t-test data: amsterdam and rotterdam t = , df = , p-value =  alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to   percent confidence interval:   sample estimates: mean ofxmeanof y   Conclusion? SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up t-test for two means of two independent samples, = Setting: Two samples: X,, Xn N(Î¼,) and Y,, Yn  N(Î¼,) We want to test about the difference in mean Î¼ âˆ’ Î¼ Assumption:  =  () () = = Hypotheses: H : Î¼ âˆ’ Î¼   versus H : Î¼ âˆ’ Î¼ >   < PP n n (Xi âˆ’XÂ¯ )+ (Yjâˆ’YÂ¯ ) Xâˆ’YÂ¯ i= j= Test statistic: T = p Â¯ , where s = is the + sn+nâˆ’ n n pooled sample variance Distribution of T under H: t-distribution with n + n âˆ’  df (exactly) In R: ttest(data,data,mu=,alt=,varequal=TRUE) SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ incomes of Amsterdam and Rotterdam () The t-test for two independent samples (Amsterdam and Rotterdam), assuming equal variances: > sd(amsterdam) []  > sd(rotterdam) []  > ttest(amsterdam,rotterdam,varequal=TRUE) Two Sample t-test data: amsterdam and rotterdam t = , df = , p-value =  alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to   percent confidence interval:   sample estimates: mean ofxmeanof y   Conclusion? For large samples there is usually no big difference between these two tests (with unequal or equal variances) SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ incomes of tax couples () (Fictive) data on incomes of  tax couples in Utrecht (couple=man+woman, tax partners) manwomanmanwoman Question: is there a difference in mean income for men and women within tax couples? SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ incomes of tax couples () We need to look at differences within pairs > d=man-woman > plot(man,woman,ylim=c(,),xlim=c(,)) > abline(,,col="red",lwd=) > hist(d,main="man-woman within couples",xlab="difference income") manwomanmanâˆ’incomeFrequencyâˆ’SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up t-test for means of matched pairs Setting: One sample (X, Y),, (Xn, Yn) of n matched pairs The differences Xi âˆ’ Yi are assumed to come from N(Î¼d,) distribution We want to test about the mean of the differences Î¼d () () = = Hypotheses: H : Î¼d   versus H : Î¼d >   < Test statistic: T = d p , where d the sample mean of differences, and sd the sd / n sample sd of differences Distribution of T under H: t-distribution with n âˆ’  df (exactly) In R: ttest(data,data,mu=,alt=,paired=TRUE) or ttest(data-data,mu=,alt=) SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ incomes of tax couples () Investigate normality of the differences within pairs and apply t-test to differences âˆ’âˆ’âˆ’Normal QuantilesSample Quantiles > ttest(man,woman,paired=TRUE) Paired t-test data: man and woman t = , df = , p-value = e- alternative hypothesis: true difference in  percent confidence interval:   sample estimates: mean of the differences  > ttest(d) One Sample t-test Conclusion? data: d t = , df = , p-value = e- means is not equal to  alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to   percent confidence interval:   sample estimates: mean of x  SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up two proportions SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ fraud fractions Utrecht and Den Haag () We test whether the fraud fraction amongst bijstand (welfare) clients is the same in Utrecht and Den Haag In a (fictive) sample amongst  bijstand clients in Utrecht we find  fraud cases and amonst  bijstand clients in Den Haag we find  fraud cases The sample fractions are pË†utrecht = / =  and pË†denhaag = / =  Question: is there a significant difference in fraud proportion between Utrecht and Den Haag? SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Testing two proportions Setting: X successes in a sample of size n taken from population  and X successes in a sample of size n from population  We want to test about the difference in population success proportion p and p () () = = Hypotheses: H : p âˆ’ p   versus H : p âˆ’ p >   < pâˆ’pË† X X x+x Test statistic: T = q Ë†ô€€€, where pË† = n , pË† = n , pÂ¯= n+n is the +  pÂ¯qÂ¯ n n pooled sample fraction and qÂ¯= âˆ’ pÂ¯ Distribution of T under H: N(, ) (approximately) In R: proptest(c(x,x),c(n,n),alt=) SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ fraud fractions Utrecht and Den Haag () We apply the approximate proportion test: > proptest(c(,),c(,)) -sample test for equality of proportions with continuity correction data: c(, ) out of c(, ) X-squared = , df = , p-value =  alternative hypothesis: twosided  percent confidence interval: -  sample estimates: prop  prop    Conclusion? SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ fraud fractions Utrecht and Den Haag () Suppose we found the same sample proportions in larger samples per city: > proptest(c(,),c(,)) -sample test for equality of proportions with continuity correction data: c(, ) out of c(, ) X-squared = , df = , p-value = e- alternative hypothesis: twosided  percent confidence interval:   sample estimates: prop  prop    Now we do reject H : putrecht = pdenhaag Why? SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up nonparametric tests SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Nonparametric tests â€“ the concept So far, in all tests we looked at the sample average which is approximately normally distributed, for, say, n >  Question: what if the data and/or test statistic are not (approx) normally distributed? Then we need a test that does not assume normality (or even any other particular distribution) of the data Nonparametric tests are valid (ie, yield reliable p-values) for a broad class of distributions of the data SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ parcels () PostNL delivered  million parcels in  Assume we are given the (fictive) dataset on total daily weights of parcels handled by PostNL on Mondays and Saturdays for all  weeks in , and we want to investigate whether there is a difference between these two week days > head(parcels) monday saturday                   > tail(parcels) monday saturday                   Histogram of saturdayweightFrequencye+e+e+ SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ parcels () The distribution of the weekly differences (monday-saturday): differencesdifferenceFrequencyâˆ’âˆ’QuantilesSample Quantiles It seems to deviate a bit from normal, the Shapiro-Wilk test yields p-value =  (reject H of normality) We will not use the t-test, but test for the median of the differences instead SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up The sign test () Setting: A sample X,, Xn from some population We want to test about the population median m Hypotheses: H : m = m versus H : m = m ô€€€ Test statistic: T =# i : Xi < m , where â€œ#â€ means â€œthe number ofâ€ Distribution of T under H: Bin(n,  ) distribution (exactly), an approximation by a normal distribution is possible In R: binomtest(t,n,p=,alt=) Setting: A sample (X, Y) , (Xn, Yn) of matched pairs from some population We want to test whether the median m of the differences is  Hypotheses: H : m =  versus H : m = ô€€€ Test statistic: T =# i : Xi < Yi Distribution of T under H: Bin(n,  ) (exactly), an approximation by a normal distribution is possible In R: binomtest(t,n,p=,alt=) SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ parcels () The sign test on the matched pairs of the parcel data: > d=monday-saturday > t=sum(d<) >t []  > length(d) []  > binomtest(,) Exact binomial test data:  and  number of successes = , number of trials = , p-value =  alternative hypothesis: true probability of success is not equal to   percent confidence interval:   sample estimates: probability of success  Conclusion? SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up The signed rank test Setting: A sample X,, Xn from some symmetric population We want to test about the population median m Hypotheses: H : m = m versus H : m = m P Test statistic: T = Ri , which is the sum of the ranks of |Xi âˆ’ m| of i:Xi >mthe observations Xi > m Large values of T indicate that m > m Distribution of T under H: is known in R For larger n an approximation by a normal distribution is used Depending on H, one-sided or two-sided test In R: wilcoxtest(data,mu=m,alt=) SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ grades Given a (real!) dataset on statistics grades of  randomly chosen students > grades=c(,,,,,,,,,,,,) > sort(grades) []              Question: are the grades symmetrically distributed around m = ? > wilcoxtest(grades,mu=) Wilcoxon signed rank test data: grades V = , p-value =  alternative hypothesis: true location is not equal to  Conclusion? SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ incomes white and colored () whitecolore+e+e+e+e+e+ Are the locations of the two income populations significantly different? SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up The rank sum test or Mann-Whitney test Setting: Two samples X,, Xn and Y,, Yn from two populations We want to test whether the populations are â€œidenticalâ€ (actually, we only test med(X) = med(Y )) Hypotheses: H : med(X) = med(Y ) versus H : med(X) = med(Y ) Pn Test statistic: T = i= Ri , which is the sum of the ranks of the Xâ€™s in the combined sample Distribution of T under H: is known in R For larger n an approximation by a normal distribution is used In R: wilcoxtest(data,data,alt=) SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up Example â€“ incomes white and colored () The Mann-Whitney U test or Wilcoxon two sample test applied on the income data: > wilcoxtest(income[,],income[,]) Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction data: income[, ] and income[, ] W = , p-value =  alternative hypothesis: true location shift is not equal to  Conclusion? SSO Lecture   /   one sample tests Shapiro-Wilk two means two proportions nonparametric tests To wrap up To wrap up Today we discussed Shapiro-Wilk test two samples tests two means (independent samples) two means (matched pairs) two proportions nonparametric tests sign test Wilcoxon signed-rank test Wilcoxon rank-sum test Next time categorical data, linear regression SSO Lecture   /
